Please refer to MOH’s daily Situation Report (&lt;a href="http://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report"&gt;www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report&lt;/a&gt;) for details.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p _rdeditor_exists="1"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br clear="all"&gt;&lt;hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"&gt;&lt;div id="ftn1"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p&gt;[1] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;[2] Based on National Immunisation Registry data.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;[3] Full regimen refers to individuals who have received both doses of the vaccine or one dose for vaccinated recovered individuals.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;[4] Fully vaccinated - more than 14 days after completing vaccination regimen (both doses of the vaccine or one dose for recovered individuals). Partially vaccinated – received 1 dose of 2-dose vaccine or COVID-positive within 14 days of completing vaccination regimen.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;[5] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div id="ftn5"&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 06 Aug 2021 15:45:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:303388f7-06db-46e0-af7e-bfc7daeaf55a</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/community-surveillance-testing-at-237-bukit-batok-east-avenue-5-51-chin-swee-road-and-683-tessensohn-road_16August2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>COMMUNITY SURVEILLANCE TESTING AT  237 BUKIT BATOK EAST AVENUE 5, 51 CHIN SWEE ROAD AND 683 TESSENSOHN ROAD</title><description>&lt;p align="center" style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; text-align: justify;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; The Ministry of Health (MOH)&amp;nbsp;is investigating likely COVID-19 transmission at 237 Bukit Batok East Avenue 5, 51 Chin Swee Road and 683 Tessensohn Road. So far,&amp;nbsp;seven cases of COVID-19 infection have been detected in four households at&amp;nbsp;237 Bukit Batok East Avenue 5. Separately, four cases of COVID-19 infection have been detected in four households at 51 Chin Swee Road, and COVID-19 viral fragments were detected in wastewater samples collected from the block.&amp;nbsp;Eight cases of COVID-19 infection have also been detected in four households at 683 Tessensohn Road.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; text-align: justify;"&gt;Epidemiological investigations are ongoing to determine linkages and the source of transmission.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;2. &amp;nbsp; In&amp;nbsp;order to uncover community infection cases, MOH will conduct&amp;nbsp;mandatory&amp;nbsp;COVID-19&amp;nbsp;testing for the following groups at designated locations on 7 August&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;2021 between 9am and 4pm.&amp;nbsp;Testing is optional for those who have tested negative for COVID-19 infection from 2 August onwards.&amp;nbsp;Please refer to the table below for details.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%"&gt;&lt;tbody&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="50%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Groups to be tested&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="49%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Designated Testing Location&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="50%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;All residents of 237 Bukit Batok East Avenue 5&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="49%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Void deck of 236 Bukit Batok East Avenue 5&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="50%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;All residents of 51 Chin Swee Road; as well as owners and staff of commercial units at the same block&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="49%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Void deck between 51 and 53 Chin Swee Road&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="50%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;All residents of 683 Tessensohn Road; as well as owners and staff of commercial units at the same block&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="49%" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Deck 4A of the multi-storey carpark at 678 Perumal Road&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;3. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;All residents are to bring along their NRIC for identification purposes.&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="color: rgb(0, 112, 192);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;Leaflets have been distributed and SMS notifications have been sent to the residents to provide them with more information. Residents are reminded to keep to their appointment time. Residents are also advised to monitor their health closely and consult a doctor immediately if they feel unwell. Those who are still awaiting their test results are advised to minimise social interactions as much as possible. They should continue to monitor their health and seek immediate medical attention if they feel unwell.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;6 AUGUST 2021&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 06 Aug 2021 13:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:b22bcf6b-f0da-4187-a037-634dc4ffeb68</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/preparing-for-our-transition-towards-covid-resilience/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Preparing For Our Transition Towards  COVID Resilience </title><description>&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The Multi-Ministry Taskforce had earlier announced the reversion to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) from &lt;strong&gt;22 July 2021&lt;/strong&gt; through &lt;strong&gt;18 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt; to allow us to contain the outbreak of clusters in the community and minimise the risk of our healthcare capacity being overwhelmed while we ramped up our vaccination rates, particularly among seniors.&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;Through the cooperation and efforts of everyone, the situation has stabilised. Infection numbers are stable and more importantly, the number of individuals with severe illnesses and deaths did not rise uncontrollably.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Preparing to be a COVID-19 Resilient Nation &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;2. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;During this period, our population vaccination rate has been going up by about one percentage-point each day. As of &lt;strong&gt;5 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, 67% of the population have completed their full vaccination regimen under the national vaccination programme and 78% have received at least one dose. Vaccination reduces the risk of infection and serious disease when infected with COVID-19. Over the last 28 days, among the 80 local cases infected with COVID-19 who are seriously ill [1], 72 are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, while only 8 are fully vaccinated. A highly vaccinated resident population is crucial to our safe reopening and transition towards an endemic COVID-19 world.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We remain concerned that unvaccinated seniors may suffer severe illness if infected. Hence, we have ramped up efforts to encourage more seniors to be vaccinated. Seniors can walk into any vaccination centre, polyclinic, or Public Health Preparedness Clinic for their vaccinations. We have also deployed mobile vaccination teams to locations where many seniors live and home vaccination teams for homebound individuals. In addition, we have roped in General Practitioners and Traditional Chinese Medicine practitioners to persuade seniors to be vaccinated. Many of our seniors have responded to these initiatives. We are also asking polyclinics and public hospitals to bring forward the appointments of seniors who are contraindicated, so that they can receive earlier advice on whether they can receive COVID-19 vaccinations. Currently, 76% of those aged 70 and above have completed two doses and 82% have received at least one dose. But there are still about 80,000 in this group that have yet to be vaccinated. As this group is at higher risk of being infected and being seriously ill if infected, we will continue efforts to help them get their vaccinations.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;By &lt;strong&gt;9 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, we expect that around 70% of our entire population would have completed two doses. This gives us some confidence that we can start to re-open our economy and resume more activities. However, we will continue to take a calibrated risk-based approach in re-opening. We will monitor health outcomes, particularly hospitalisation and ICU cases, to avoid exponential increases that could overwhelm our healthcare capacity.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;In particular, we will adopt a vaccination-differentiated approach when adjusting our safe management and border measures. Fully vaccinated individuals, who have good protection against the risk of infection or severe illnesses, will be able to engage in a wider range of activities. Unvaccinated individuals will need to exercise tighter safe management measures to protect themselves and those around them.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Even with high vaccination coverage, we may still have vaccine breakthroughs and a large number of daily COVID-19 cases within the community. Nevertheless, with the majority of our population protected through vaccination, we should be able to keep hospitalisation and ICU cases low. We will continue to monitor the situation, especially the incidence of severe illness from COVID-19, as we continue with our re-opening plans.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Updates in Healthcare Protocols.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As we prepare for the transition towards COVID resilience, we have reviewed our medical management protocols for our COVID-19 patients. With evidence emerging that vaccinated individuals can recover within 10 days from illness onset, we have moved to discharge fully vaccinated persons earlier at Day 10 from isolation if their PCR test shows that they are COVID-19 negative or have very low viral loads. Others who do not meet the criteria will continue to be discharged after 14 days of isolation without any further testing, with an additional 7 days’ leave of absence. This approach gives us assurance that cases will not pose transmission risks to their family and community upon discharge.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Updates to Safe Management Measures from 10 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We have also undertaken a mid-point review of the Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures, and will allow some easing of the measures in two steps. The first will take effect from &lt;strong&gt;10 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, and the second from &lt;strong&gt;19 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, if conditions remain stable. Please refer to &lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider5/default-document-library/annex-a009bdc806d184cc5b22010612ba0702e.pdf?sfvrsn=7d83906b_0" title="Annex A"&gt;Annex A&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;for details.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;(A)&amp;nbsp; Increase in Social Gathering Group Size&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; We will increase the current social gathering group size limit from 2 persons to &lt;strong&gt;5 persons &lt;/strong&gt;and increase the cap of 2 distinct visitors per household per day to 5 distinct visitors per household per day. Unvaccinated individuals should remain in groups of no more than 2 persons, to reduce the likelihood of transmission and severe infection. We should also continue to limit our social circle to a small group of regular contacts and limit the number of social gatherings to no more than two a day.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;(B) Updates on Vaccination-Differentiated Safe Management Measures and Eligibility &lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;With better protection against infection and severe illness, &lt;strong&gt;fully-vaccinated individuals may participate, in groups of up to 5 persons, in higher-risk activities where masks are removed&lt;/strong&gt;, e.g. Food &amp;amp; Beverage (F&amp;amp;B) dine-in, personal care services, indoor high-intensity mask-off sports; and in &lt;strong&gt;larger events &lt;/strong&gt;e.g. solemnizations, congregational and other worship services.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;11.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; With higher vaccination coverage under our national vaccination programme, we can take a more inclusive approach in recognising COVID-19 vaccines in the World Health Organisation’s Emergency Use Listing (WHO EUL). From &lt;strong&gt;10 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, individuals who are fully vaccinated with the WHO EUL vaccines such as Sinovac-CoronaVac, Sinopharm, and AstraZeneca will be eligible for the vaccination-differentiated safe management measures.Thus, an individual will be considered “fully-vaccinated” two weeks after he or she has received the full regimen of Pfizer-BioNTech/ Comirnaty, Moderna, or any WHO EUL vaccines.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;12.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Unvaccinated individuals with a valid negative pre-event test result or recovered individuals are of similarly lower risk, and may also join in such groups of up to 5.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;u&gt;Resumption of Dining-in at F&amp;amp;B Establishments for Vaccinated Groups&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;13.&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Groups of up to 5 persons&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;strong&gt;will be allowed to dine-in at F&amp;amp;B establishments if all the diners are fully vaccinated&lt;/strong&gt;. Unvaccinated children aged 12 years and below may be included within the group of 5 persons &lt;strong&gt;as long as all the children are from the same household&lt;/strong&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;14.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Individual F&amp;amp;B establishments may only resume dine-in services for fully vaccinated persons as outlined above. F&amp;amp;B establishments that are not able to ensure this may only operate take-away and delivery services.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;15.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Hawker centres and coffee shops provide convenient and affordable food services within the community. As these are open-air and naturally ventilated spaces, we will extend a special concession for both vaccinated and unvaccinated persons to dine in the hawker centres and coffee shops. But this will be subject to a smaller group size of up to &lt;strong&gt;2 persons only.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;16.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Dining-in at F&amp;amp;B establishments remains a high-risk activity because many people will be unmasked and in close proximity with each other. At this stage of the transition, entertainment such as live performances, recorded music, and videos/TV screening will continue to be prohibited. Patrons to F&amp;amp;B establishments are also reminded to adhere to all safe management measures and keep their masks on at all times except when eating or drinking.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;(C)&amp;nbsp; Increase in Event Size and Capacity Limits&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;17.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The following event sizes and capacity limits will be increased. The provision for children aged 12 years and below will also apply for these events. Unvaccinated children may be included in a group of up to 5 persons if all the children are from the same household.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;a)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Congregational and other worship services, cinemas, MICE, live performances, and spectator sport events&lt;/u&gt;. Event sizes may increase to 500 attendees if all are fully vaccinated. Otherwise, only up to 50 attendees will be allowed without pre-event testing (PET). Unmasking and singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances for vaccinated performers may resume, subject to updated safe management measures. Further details on live performances will be released by the National Arts Council (NAC). Further details on worship services will be released by the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;b)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Marriage solemnizations and wedding receptions&lt;/u&gt;. Marriage solemnizations in external venues (i.e. not in a place of residence or in the Registry of Marriages/Registry of Muslim Marriages building) may take place with up to 500 persons (including the wedding couple but excluding solemnizers and vendors) if all are fully vaccinated. Otherwise, only up to 50 attendees will be allowed without PET. Wedding receptions will be allowed with up to 250 attendees if all are fully vaccinated, and with groups of up to 5 attendees per table.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adjustments from 19 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;18.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; If the COVID-19 situation remains under control, we will further increase event sizes and capacity limits for the following activities and settings from &lt;strong&gt;19 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;a)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Congregational and other worship services, cinemas, MICE, live performances, spectator sport events, and marriage solemnizations.&lt;/u&gt; These events may take place with up to 1,000 attendees if all are fully vaccinated. Otherwise, only up to 50 attendees will be allowed without PET.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;b)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Attractions, cruises, museums, and public libraries&lt;/u&gt;. The operating capacity of attractions and cruises will be increased from the current capacity of 25% to 50%. Museums and public libraries will also be allowed to operate at an increased operating capacity of 50%.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;c)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Shopping malls and showrooms.&lt;/u&gt; The occupancy limits for shopping malls and showrooms will be increased from the current limit of 16 sqm per person of Gross Floor Area, to 10 sqm per person.&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;19.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;u&gt;Work-from-home.&lt;/u&gt; We will also ease the work-from-home requirements. In particular up to 50% of employees who are able to work from home will be allowed to return to the workplace.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;Removal of Temperature Screening Requirement&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;20.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; With high levels of vaccine coverage among our population, transmission among vaccinated individuals and disease severity in vaccinated but infected persons are likely to be substantially lower. In addition, we now have the ability to pick up infections earlier through increased surveillance measures including self-test antigen rapid test (ART) kits and rostered routine testing with fast and easy tests (FETs) in higher risk settings. With these other targeted public health tools, we will remove the requirement for temperature screening in public premises, together with the other relaxation of measures planned from &lt;strong&gt;19 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt; onwards. Nevertheless, it is important to continue exercising good health-seeking behaviour when one is unwell by seeking care as soon as possible, using a mask and avoiding crowded places.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Transition towards COVID-19 Resilience&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;21.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Looking ahead, when at least 80% of our population have received their full vaccination regimens, we will be able to take the next steps towards opening up our economy, social activities, and travel. At that stage, we can consider further easing of restrictions, while continuing with differentiated safe distancing rules for vaccinated and unvaccinated persons. We will make these moves in a controlled manner, synchronising the easing with our vaccination coverage, and seeking to minimise the incidence of severe illness and death.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;“Vaccinate or Regular Test” Regime for Selected Sectors of the Workforce &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;22.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Although Singapore’s vaccination rates are one of the highest in the world, we need to continue to expand our vaccine coverage. Hence we will require vaccination, or regular testing in lieu, for selected sectors of the workforce. Unvaccinated persons will be required to undergo regular testing to pick up possible infections early so that they can be treated early. This will also mitigate risk of transmission to their colleagues and the public.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;23.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This “vaccinate or regular test” regime will be introduced in the following settings:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;a)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;First for those working in the &lt;u&gt;healthcare sector, eldercare sector and &lt;/u&gt;&lt;u&gt;settings with children 12 years and below&lt;/u&gt;. This protects vulnerable segments of the population such as the elderly, children and sick.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;b)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Second, for &lt;u&gt;individuals working in sectors that interact with customers in higher-risk mask-off settings, and at our borders or COVID-19 frontline work&lt;/u&gt;. These sectors include F&amp;amp;B establishments, gyms and fitness studios, and personal care services.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;c)&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Finally, the &lt;u&gt;Public Service&lt;/u&gt; will take the lead in introducing this requirement for public officers, including the uniformed services.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;24.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; We will give some time for individuals to get vaccinated, thus the requirement will take effect from &lt;strong&gt;1 October&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;strong&gt;2021&lt;/strong&gt;. Beyond that, any unvaccinated persons from the above sectors will have to be tested with an ART kit twice a week. For the small group that remains medically ineligible for vaccines, the Government will subsidise their tests.&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;25.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;More details will be released by the respective Ministries overseeing the sectors. We strongly encourage all employers to facilitate vaccination for your employees. A fully vaccinated workforce ensures a safe workplace and safe environment for everyone. We will continue to closely monitor our vaccination rates and review the need to include other sectors in the future.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Vaccination-Differentiated Border Measures&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;26.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As we have reached higher vaccination rates locally, we will progressively review some of our border restrictions to facilitate more travel and introduce vaccination-differentiated border measures for travellers from countries/regions that have shown an ability to control the pandemic and vaccinate large parts of their population.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;Resuming Entry Approvals for Vaccinated Work Pass Holders and Their Dependants&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;27.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;From &lt;strong&gt;10 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, the Ministry of Manpower will resume entry approvals for work pass holders and their dependants with travel history to higher risk countries/ regions. Eligible work pass holders and their dependants must be fully vaccinated&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt; before arrival in Singapore. They will also be subjected to the prevailing health protocols in Singapore.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;Option for 14-day Stay Home Notice (SHN) at Suitable Place of Residence/ Accommodation of Choice&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;28.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;From &lt;strong&gt;20 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;, &lt;strong&gt;2359 hrs,&lt;/strong&gt; all &lt;strong&gt;fully vaccinated travellers [2]&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;from &lt;strong&gt;Australia, Austria, Canada, Germany, Italy, Norway, the Republic of Korea (ROK), and Switzerland [3]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;may be able to apply to opt out of dedicated SHN facilities and serve their 14-day SHN at their respective places of residence (e.g. residential address) or other suitable accommodation if they fulfil certain criteria (See &lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider5/default-document-library/annex-b03e76bfa0fff4e69981a640008b9c532.pdf?sfvrsn=681825a1_0" title="Annex B"&gt;Annex B&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; for details).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;29.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;All other travellers from the aforementioned countries/regions must continue to serve the SHN in a dedicated SHN facility. As the list of countries will be updated from time to time depending on the public health risk assessment, all travellers are reminded to check the SafeTravel website for updates to the border measures. They will be subjected to these prevailing border measures upon entry, including stays in dedicated SHN facilities and payment, where applicable.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Towards a Resilient Singapore living with COVID-19 &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;30.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We have made significant progress in vaccinating the Singapore population. We must continue to push for higher vaccination coverage so that in time to come, we may be able to treat COVID-19 no differently from other diseases that are endemic to Singapore. It will then not dominate our lives but become part of our new normal. We may continue to see relatively high number of daily cases, but the majority of vaccinated individuals will recover, and we can focus on the smaller number of cases with severe illnesses or infections. We will continue to find means to manage any new or emerging variants, and review strategies such as vaccination boosters for the population. We thank Singaporeans for your cooperation in these efforts. We must continue to work together in this journey towards a COVID-19 resilient nation.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div&gt;&lt;br clear="all"&gt; &lt;hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"&gt; &lt;div id="ftn1"&gt; &lt;p&gt;[1] This refers to requiring oxygen supplementation, admission to ICU, or having passed away. &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn2"&gt; &lt;p&gt;[2] An individual is considered fully-vaccinated two weeks after he or she has received the full regimen of Pfizer-BioNTech/ Comirnaty, Moderna or WHO EUL vaccines.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn3"&gt; &lt;p&gt;[3] Travellers from Israel are no longer allowed to opt out of SHN at dedicated SHN facilities due to the increase in cases.&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 06 Aug 2021 10:30:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:0018448f-9dae-48cc-b970-b8a82cd31d4f</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/93-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-covid-19-infection/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>93 New Cases of Locally Transmitted  COVID-19 Infection</title><description>&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 6 August 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has preliminarily confirmed 93 new cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. 56 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 8 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 29 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases is 1 senior above 70 years who is partially vaccinated, and is at risk of serious illness. &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In addition, there are 4 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. All were detected upon arrival in Singapore.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 97 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 06 Aug 2021 10:30:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:6c4db20b-9470-4a65-9f4e-945437f35373</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-local-covid-19-situation-(5-aug-2021)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>UPDATE ON LOCAL COVID-19 SITUATION (5 AUG 2021)</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 5 August 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed and verified that there are 96 cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. 38 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 20 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 38 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 2 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There are 2 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 1 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 98 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 1:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Local Unlinked Cases and Linked Cases by Already Quarantined/ Detected through Surveillance&lt;sup&gt;[1]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig1(5aug).png?sfvrsn=9eaff32a_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig1(5aug).png?sfvrsn=9eaff32a_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig1(5Aug)" title="Fig1(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Progress of national vaccination programme&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 4 August 2021, 65% of our population has completed their full regimen/ received two doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme, and 78% has received at least one dose. In total, we have administered a total of 7,831,520 doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme, covering 4,337,397 individuals, with 3,618,488 individuals having completed the full vaccination regimen. In addition, 115,970 doses of Sinovac vaccines have been administered as of 4 August 2021, covering 77,095 individuals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 2: &lt;/strong&gt;Percentage of Total Population who Received At Least First Dose&lt;sup&gt;[2] &lt;/sup&gt;and Completed Full Regimen&lt;sup&gt;[3]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig2(5aug).png?sfvrsn=105a9911_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig2(5aug).png?sfvrsn=105a9911_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig2(5Aug)" title="Fig2(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;Figure 3:&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Vaccinated Individuals who Received At Least First Dose by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig3(5aug).png?sfvrsn=5e68b108_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig3(5aug).png?sfvrsn=5e68b108_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig3(5Aug)" title="Fig3(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 4: &lt;/strong&gt;Percentage of Individuals who Completed Full Regimen of COVID-19 Vaccine by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig4(5aug).png?sfvrsn=f4b6b157_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig4(5aug).png?sfvrsn=f4b6b157_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig4(5Aug)" title="Fig4(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;Figure 5: &lt;/strong&gt;Total number of doses administered&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig5(5aug).png?sfvrsn=5b6a6666_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig5(5aug).png?sfvrsn=5b6a6666_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig5(5Aug)" title="Fig5(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Condition of confirmed cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;577 cases are currently warded in hospital.&amp;nbsp; Most are well and under observation. There are currently 40 cases of serious illness requiring oxygen supplementation, and 8 in critical condition in the intensive care unit (ICU). 7 amongst these 48 cases are fully vaccinated. Of these, 5 require oxygen supplementation while 2 require ICU care as they have underlying medical conditions. 36 seniors above 60 years, of whom 31 are completely unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, have fallen very ill.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Case 67610, a 79 year-old male Singaporean, has passed away from complications due to COVID-19 infection on 4 August 2021. He had sought medical treatment at Sengkang General Hospital on 4 August for shortness of breath and low blood pressure, and was confirmed to have COVID-19 infection on the same day. He had not been vaccinated against COVID-19, and had a history of heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hypertension. In total, 40 have passed away from complications due to COVID-19 infection.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 6: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig6(5aug).png?sfvrsn=dbb9696c_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig6(5aug).png?sfvrsn=dbb9696c_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig6(5Aug)" title="Fig6(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 7: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig7(5aug).png?sfvrsn=4f0e7f5f_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig7(5aug).png?sfvrsn=4f0e7f5f_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig7(5Aug)" title="Fig7(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There is continuing evidence that vaccination helps to prevent serious disease when one gets infected. Over the last 28 days, 80 local cases required oxygen supplementation, were admitted to ICU or passed away. 48 are unvaccinated, 24 are partially vaccinated and 8 are fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 8:&lt;/strong&gt; Local Cases in the Last 28 Days by Vaccination Status &amp;amp; Severity of Condition&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig8(5aug).png?sfvrsn=95034fff_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig8(5aug).png?sfvrsn=95034fff_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig8(5Aug)" title="Fig8(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 9:&lt;/strong&gt; Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;by Vaccination Status&lt;sup&gt;[4]&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig9(5aug).png?sfvrsn=6ffff41b_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig9(5aug).png?sfvrsn=6ffff41b_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig9(5Aug)" title="Fig9(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for local cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Overall, the number of new cases in the community has decreased from 881 cases in the week before to 723 cases in the past week. The number of unlinked cases in the community has increased from 223 cases in the week before to 228 cases in the past week. The 7-day moving average number of all linked community cases and all unlinked community cases are 70.7 and 32.6 respectively.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 10: &lt;/strong&gt;7 Day Moving Average Number of Community Unlinked and Linked Cases&lt;sup&gt;[5]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig10(5aug).png?sfvrsn=5964947f_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig10(5aug).png?sfvrsn=5964947f_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig10(5Aug)" title="Fig10(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 11: &lt;/strong&gt;Local Cases in the Last 14 Days by Age Group and Vaccination Status&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig11(5aug).png?sfvrsn=2df7bc36_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig11(5aug).png?sfvrsn=2df7bc36_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig11(5Aug)" title="Fig11(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for imported cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are a total of 2 imported cases today. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 1 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 12:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Imported Cases by Detected Upon Arrival/&amp;nbsp;Detected during SHN or Isolation&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig12(5aug).png?sfvrsn=f6e80612_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig12(5aug).png?sfvrsn=f6e80612_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig12(5Aug)" title="Fig12(5Aug)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Active clusters under monitoring&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are 10 new clusters today. In total, there are currently 122 active clusters, ranging between 3 and 1,127 infections.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 13: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active Clusters&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig13(5aug).png?sfvrsn=9c4c15dd_0"&gt;&lt;img align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 67651 &lt;em&gt;(new cluster)&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p 67278&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;1&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;4&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 67534&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;1&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;4&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kian Hiap align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;div&gt;* Please refer to &lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider5/default-document-library/annex-a58d8a9b33c3a41b395af573b18449e3d.pdf?sfvrsn=33e2e83d_0" title="Annex A"&gt;Annex A&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;for the affected markets and food centres.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;11.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Please refer to MOH’s daily Situation Report (&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report"&gt;www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report&lt;/a&gt;) for details.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;5 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"&gt;&lt;div id="ftn1"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;sup&gt;[1] &lt;/sup&gt;Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;br&gt;&lt;sup&gt;[2] &lt;/sup&gt;Based on National Immunisation Registry data.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;sup&gt;[3] &lt;/sup&gt;Full regimen refers to individuals who have received both doses of the vaccine or one dose for vaccinated recovered individuals.&lt;br&gt;&lt;sup&gt;[4]&lt;/sup&gt; Fully vaccinated - more than 14 days after completing vaccination regimen (both doses of the vaccine or one dose for recovered individuals). Partially vaccinated – received 1 dose of 2-dose vaccine or COVID-positive within 14 days of completing vaccination regimen.&lt;br&gt;&lt;sup&gt;[5]&lt;/sup&gt; Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;br&gt;&lt;sup&gt;[6]&lt;/sup&gt; Includes new cases added today.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Aug 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:af54cf2e-4882-44a2-a3ab-3e3019db652d</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/updates-on-border-measures-for-travellers-from-taiwan5aug/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Updates on Border Measures For Travellers From Taiwan</title><description>&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The Multi-Ministry Taskforce has been closely monitoring the global COVID-19 situation. As the situation in Taiwan has improved, we will allow travellers from Taiwan to undergo a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test upon arrival, and to go about their activities in Singapore if the PCR test result is negative.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Updated Border Measures for Travellers from Taiwan&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We had earlier announced that travellers from Taiwan will be subjected to an on-arrival COVID-19 PCR test, a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) at a dedicated SHN facility (or opt out to serve at their place of residence), and a COVID-19 PCR test before the end of the SHN period.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As the situation in Taiwan has improved:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;a.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; From&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;7 August 2021, 2359 hours&lt;/strong&gt;, all travellers entering Singapore with travel history to Taiwan, within the last 21 days before departure for Singapore, will undergo a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival [1], and will be allowed to go about their activities in Singapore if the PCR test result is negative. They will not need to serve a 14-day SHN period.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;b.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Short-term visitors with travel history to Taiwan, within the last 21 days before departure for Singapore, can apply for an Air Travel Pass with immediate effect, for entry into Singapore on or after&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;12 August 2021&lt;/strong&gt;. They will undergo a COVID-19 PCR test upon arrival, and will be allowed to go about their activities in Singapore if the PCR test result is negative.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;c.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Travellers who are already serving their 14-day SHN at their place of residence as of 7 August 2021, 2359 hours will still be required to complete their 14-day SHN and exit swab.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Regular Review of Border Measures&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As the global situation evolves, we will continue to adjust our border measures to manage the risk of importation and transmission to the community. Any changes to border measures will be updated on the&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/"&gt;SafeTravel website&lt;/a&gt;. Travellers are advised to visit the website to check for the most updated border measures before entering Singapore and be prepared to be subjected to the prevailing border measures upon entry.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br clear="all"&gt;&lt;hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"&gt;&lt;div id="ftn1"&gt;&lt;p&gt;[1] To expedite the COVID-19 PCR test at the checkpoints, travellers are strongly encouraged to register and pre-pay for their on-arrival COVID-19 PCR test prior to departing for Singapore at&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="https://safetravel.changiairport.com/"&gt;https://safetravel.changiairport.com/&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;(for Changi Airport) and&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href="https://t.2c2p.com/express/parkwayshenton"&gt;https://t.2c2p.com/express/parkwayshenton&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;(for Tanah Merah Ferry Terminal).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Aug 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:7754eda2-728f-40bb-9d87-8c4925fb6319</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/96-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-covid-19-infection(5Aug2021)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>96 NEW CASES OF LOCALLY TRANSMITTED COVID-19 INFECTION</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 5 August 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has preliminarily confirmed 96 new cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. 38 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 20 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 38 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 2 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In addition, there are 2 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 1 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 98 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;5 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;</description><pubDate>Thu, 05 Aug 2021 09:55:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:6955ec30-c6b3-47c9-841e-7326f4d2d7a7</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-local-covid-19-situation-(4-aug-2021)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title> UPDATE ON LOCAL COVID-19 SITUATION (4 AUG 2021)</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 4 August 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed and verified that there are 92 cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. 54 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 8 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 30 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases is 1 senior above 70 years who is unvaccinated, and is at risk of serious illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There are 3 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 2 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 95 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 1:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Local Unlinked Cases and Linked Cases by Already Quarantined/ Detected through Surveillance&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure01_4aug.png?sfvrsn=4542a2cd_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure01_4aug.png?sfvrsn=4542a2cd_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure01_4Aug" title="Figure01_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Progress of national vaccination programme&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 3 August 2021, 64% of our population has completed their full regimen/ received two doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme, and 77% has received at least one dose. In total, we have administered a total of 7,767,442 doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme, covering 4,329,956 individuals, with 3,561,452 individuals having completed the full vaccination regimen. In addition, 113,767 doses of Sinovac vaccines have been administered as of 3 August 2021, covering 76,571 individuals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 2:&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Total Population who Received At Least First Dose&lt;sup&gt;2 &lt;/sup&gt;and Completed Full Regimen&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure02_4aug.png?sfvrsn=ff1634a0_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure02_4aug.png?sfvrsn=ff1634a0_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure02_4Aug" title="Figure02_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 3:&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Vaccinated Individuals who Received At Least First Dose by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure03_4aug.png?sfvrsn=1590a82f_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure03_4aug.png?sfvrsn=1590a82f_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure03_4Aug" title="Figure03_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 4:&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Individuals who Completed Full Regimen of COVID-19 Vaccine by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure04_4aug.png?sfvrsn=ad995b02_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure04_4aug.png?sfvrsn=ad995b02_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure04_4Aug" title="Figure04_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 5:&lt;/strong&gt; Total number of doses administered&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure05_4aug.png?sfvrsn=77b31ad9_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure05_4aug.png?sfvrsn=77b31ad9_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure05_4Aug" title="Figure05_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Condition of confirmed cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; 555 cases are currently warded in hospital.&amp;nbsp; Most are well and under observation. There are currently 42 cases of serious illness requiring oxygen supplementation, and 7 in critical condition in the intensive care unit (ICU). 8 amongst these 49 cases are fully vaccinated. Of these, 6 require oxygen supplementation while 2 require ICU care as they have underlying medical conditions. 37 seniors above 60 years, of whom 31 are completely unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, have fallen very ill.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Case 66894, a 58 year-old female Singaporean, has passed away from complications due to COVID-19 infection on 2 August 2021. She was a household contact of a case who had visited Samy’s Curry Restaurant, and was confirmed to have COVID-19 infection on 29 July. She had not been vaccinated against COVID-19, and had no underlying medical condition. In total, 39 have passed away from complications due to COVID-19 infection.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 6:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure06_4aug.png?sfvrsn=ce7e0609_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure06_4aug.png?sfvrsn=ce7e0609_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure06_4Aug" title="Figure06_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 7: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation, by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure07_4aug.png?sfvrsn=87364fe3_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure07_4aug.png?sfvrsn=87364fe3_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure07_4Aug" title="Figure07_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There is continuing evidence that vaccination helps to prevent serious disease when one gets infected. Over the last 28 days, 77 local cases required oxygen supplementation, were admitted to ICU or passed away. 45 are unvaccinated, 24 are partially vaccinated and 8 are fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 8: &lt;/strong&gt;Local Cases in the Last 28 Days by Vaccination Status &amp;amp; Severity of Condition&lt;sup&gt;4&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure08_4aug.png?sfvrsn=cb76607d_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure08_4aug.png?sfvrsn=cb76607d_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure08_4Aug" title="Figure08_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 9: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;by Vaccination Status&lt;sup&gt;4&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure09_4aug.png?sfvrsn=cbfb383e_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure09_4aug.png?sfvrsn=cbfb383e_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure09_4Aug" title="Figure09_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for local cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Overall, the number of new cases in the community has decreased from 915 cases in the week before to 758 cases in the past week. We are likely to continue to see high number of cases in the coming days as we step up efforts to detect them to contain their spread in the community. The number of unlinked cases in the community has increased from 202 cases in the week before to 235 cases in the past week. The 7-day moving average number of all linked community cases and all unlinked community cases are 74.7 and 33.6 respectively.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 10: &lt;/strong&gt;7 Day Moving Average Number of Community Unlinked and Linked Cases&lt;sup&gt;5&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure10_4aug.png?sfvrsn=5d5255d6_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure10_4aug.png?sfvrsn=5d5255d6_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure10_4Aug" title="Figure10_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 11:&lt;/strong&gt; Local Cases in the Last 14 Days by Age Group and Vaccination Status&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure11_4aug.png?sfvrsn=670a5832_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure11_4aug.png?sfvrsn=670a5832_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure11_4Aug" title="Figure11_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;Summary of trends for imported cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are a total of 3 imported cases today. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 2 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 12:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Imported Cases by Detected Upon Arrival/Detected during SHN or Isolation&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure12_4aug.png?sfvrsn=141b99d3_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure12_4aug.png?sfvrsn=141b99d3_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure12_4Aug" title="Figure12_4Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Active clusters under monitoring&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are 12 new clusters today. In total, there are currently 112 active clusters, ranging between 3 and 1,115 infections.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 13: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active Clusters&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure13_4aug.png?sfvrsn=eb1caaf3_0"&gt;&lt;img 65979&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;Case 65132&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;Case 66168&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;Case 65846&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;Case
