Those who are 60 years old and above can additionally tap on the Flexi-MediSave scheme for outpatient expenses.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-b1f3e11a-7fff-621f-dd75-b20b4e7c1960" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;2&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;To ensure that no Singaporean is denied access to appropriate treatment due to inability to pay, MediFund is available at PHIs as a safety net to assist Singaporeans who are unable to afford their mental health treatments despite Government subsidies, insurance and MediSave.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-b1f3e11a-7fff-621f-dd75-b20b4e7c1960" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;3&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;MOH reviews the various financial schemes regularly to ensure they meet the needs of Singaporeans. For example, the MediSave annual withdrawal limit for patients with complex chronic conditions was increased from $500 to $700 from Jan 2021. The annual limit for Flexi-MediSave was also increased from $200 to $300 from Jun 2021. Since 1 Mar 2021, the MediShield Life claim limits for inpatient mental health treatment was raised to $160 per day for up to 60 days per policy year, from the previous $100 per day for up to 35 days per policy year, which will help to improve patient affordability.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 12:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:97d74513-74f9-4bc4-a0d8-00cc0a24be34</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/edicated-care-for-long-covid-19-patients/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>DEDICATED CARE FOR LONG-COVID-19 PATIENTS</title><description>&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-5042f405-7fff-34e0-ad09-bc80d1a2c24b" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE PAPER NO. 571&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE OF QUESTION FOR ORAL ANSWER&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;FOR THE SITTING OF PARLIAMENT ON 2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-5042f405-7fff-34e0-ad09-bc80d1a2c24b" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Ms He Ting Ru&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;MP for Sengkang GRC&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-5042f405-7fff-34e0-ad09-bc80d1a2c24b" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question No. 1470&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-5042f405-7fff-34e0-ad09-bc80d1a2c24b" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) what is the total number of cases of long-COVID diagnosed and logged in Singapore since the figure of zero reported in November 2020, broken down by gender and age group, (b) what are the plans for dedicated, integrated care for long-COVID patients, including physiological and psychological care; and (c) what measures have been taken to support patients with long-COVID symptoms.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-5042f405-7fff-34e0-ad09-bc80d1a2c24b" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Answer&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 12pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;‘Long COVID’ is not a distinct medical condition or a formal diagnosis and refers to persons who have continued symptoms of COVID-19 infection. The underlying reasons for continued symptoms vary, as do the symptoms themselves. We continue to offer care to all these patients, who require support from different clinical teams depending on their condition.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 12pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;2&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;A multi-centre study led by the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) showed that one in ten COVID-19 patients who recovered after the initial infection continued to display symptoms such as cough or breathlessness 6 months after resolution of the acute illness. Those aged above 65 years and who had severe infection were associated with an increased likelihood of these persistent symptoms.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 12:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:e92a5a8d-6d21-4a4a-95ff-9f4a298504d5</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/average-interval-between-exposure-to-covid-19-case-and-issuance-of-quarantine-order/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>AVERAGE INTERVAL BETWEEN EXPOSURE TO COVID-19 CASE AND ISSUANCE OF QUARANTINE ORDER</title><description>&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE PAPER NO. 571&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE OF QUESTION FOR ORAL ANSWER&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;FOR THE SITTING OF PARLIAMENT ON 2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Mr Chua Kheng Wee Louis&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;MP for Sengkang GRC&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Question No. 1453&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;To ask the Minister for Health for Quarantine Orders (QO) that have been issued to persons identified as close contacts of COVID-19 cases (a) what are the average and longest time intervals from the day of their exposure to the infected individual, to the day the QO is served; and (b) how has the average speed of isolating close contacts of COVID-19 cases changed since the start of the year.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Answer&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: justify;"&gt;1&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of Jul 2021, the mean time to issue the QO from notification of case was 2 days.&amp;nbsp; The longest time interval was 14 days.&amp;nbsp; This happened for a small number of individuals, where it was particularly difficult to trace the contacts of the infected.&amp;nbsp; The mean time in Jan 2021 was shorter – 1.5 days, as we had fewer daily cases then.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: justify; font-size: 16px;"&gt;While on the subject we would like to record our appreciation for the men and women who work 24/7 on the contact tracing and quarantine ops, as they are a vital enabler for our COVID19 strategy, and we urge members of the public to cooperate with their requests for information, so that we can all be better protected.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-f8c5a898-7fff-2c76-6934-34d3453c2fb1" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 12:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:ebd2c5eb-44fd-4c51-9302-658ad1ce70a6</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/breakdown-of-13.6-million-swab-tests-performed/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title> BREAKDOWN OF 13.6 MILLION SWAB TESTS PERFORMED</title><description>&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE PAPER NO. 571&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE OF QUESTION FOR WRITTEN ANSWER&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;FOR THE SITTING OF PARLIAMENT ON 2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Dr Tan Yia Swam&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Nominated MP&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;h2 dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question No. 949&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) of the 13.6 million swab tests that have been performed, what is the breakdown into (i) symptomatic patients (ii) close contacts of confirmed positive COVID-19 cases and (iii) Rostered Routine Testing (RRT) respectively; and (b) how many positive cases were picked up after symptomatic patients have the deep nasal swab and RRT respectively.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;h6 dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Answer&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h6&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;1&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span class="Apple-tab-span"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Testing is a key enabler in our efforts to contain COVID-19. As of 30 Jun 2021, 1176 of close to 127,000 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) swab tests conducted on close contacts of COVID-19 infected individuals were found to be COVID-19 positive. Additionally, about 959,000 PCR swab tests were conducted on individuals who had respiratory symptoms and presented themselves at our Public Health Preparedness Clinics and Polyclinics. Of these, about 255 tested COVID-19 positive.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;2&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span class="Apple-tab-span"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Workers in higher risk settings such as our borders, the Construction, Marine and Process (CMP) sectors, inpatient healthcare, as well those living in high density environments such as dorms undergo rostered routine testing (RRT). As of 30 Jun 2021, there are about 550,000 workers&amp;nbsp; who are undergoing PCR RRT, of which 536 of them had tested COVID-19 positive.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;3&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span class="Apple-tab-span"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;RRT allows us to detect and ringfence cases early. It protects workers, and limits the spread of COVID-19, by allowing us to detect spread early, and intervene. RRT also helps us focus public health resources where it is needed. Positive test results allow rapid intervention to protect workplaces and the community. Negative test results are also useful as it provides reassurance to the workers and their clients, and allow these groups of employees in critical roles, to avoid facing further restrictions on social activities.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-9e1e204c-7fff-dff8-cf04-8ed27cd7a207" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 12:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:233d170f-b131-42ee-8aad-f53552b4d02a</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/public-education-by-hsa-on-identifying-medical-and-surgical-masks-meeting-en-14683-astm-f2100-standards-and-requirement-for-e-commerce-platforms-to-ensure-masks-sold-meet-standards/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>PUBLIC EDUCATION BY HSA ON IDENTIFYING MEDICAL AND SURGICAL MASKS MEETING EN 14683/ASTM F2100 STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENT FOR E-COMMERCE PLATFORMS TO ENSURE MASKS SOLD MEET STANDARDS</title><description>&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE PAPER NO.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px;"&gt;NOTICE OF QUESTION FOR WRITTEN ANSWER&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;FOR THE SITTING OF PARLIAMENT ON 2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Mr Chua Kheng Wee Louis&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;MP for Sengkang GRC&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question No. 948&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) whether HSA will consider public education for Singaporeans on identifying medical and surgical masks that meet the EN 14683 / ASTM F2100 standards; and (b) whether HSA will require e-commerce platforms to check that the surgical masks that they sell are of the necessary standard.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Answer&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;HSA has published a guideline titled “What you need to know about masks” which provides information on the specifications of good quality medical and surgical masks.&amp;nbsp; HSA also licenses manufacturers of medical and surgical masks, which requires them to meet standards, such as the EN 14683 or ASTM F2100, which are adopted by the European Union and USA respectively. A list of locally manufactured&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: rgb(255, 0, 0); background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;medical and surgical masks that have been tested and verified to meet these standards has also been published by HSA on their website.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" style="margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="background-color: transparent; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Importers of medical and surgical masks are required to notify HSA and submit test reports to show that their products meet a minimum bacterial filtration efficiency based on the EN 14683 or ASTM F2100.&amp;nbsp; HSA also engages the various e-commerce platform administrators on an on-going basis, to check on the vendors selling medical and surgical masks on their platforms, and ensure that the masks on sale are from HSA licensed local manufacturers, or importers with evidence of import notification to HSA.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-d1a3394c-7fff-0963-dfca-2ea9d0905fcd" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 12:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:c0d7bcb5-c1e4-4fbb-b513-1b2678c4a167</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/response-to-adjournment-motion-on-improving-access-and-sustainability-of-the-rare-disease-fund-2-august-2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Response to Adjournment Motion on “Improving access and sustainability of the Rare Disease Fund”, 2 August 2021</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Speaker, Sir, having a child born with a rare disease can be a life-changing event for the entire family. In addition to the suffering that the child goes through, it also creates a lot of emotional distress, uncertainties and anxieties for the parents and can impose greater financial demand and physical demand in the caring for the needs of the child. The high cost of treatment adds to the overall burden. As a doctor, I have walked this journey with many patients and their family before, especially when they have an expected diagnosis being revealed to them.&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; I would like to thank Ms Cheryl Chan for her passionate speech and proposals relating to the Rare Disease Fund (RDF) in support of these families. The Government shares her concern for individuals with rare diseases where medication is very costly and required for life. This was why in 2019, the Government provided a generous matching of $3 for every $1 of public donation to establish the RDF as a charity fund to support Singapore Citizens diagnosed with rare genetic diseases.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The RDF supports high cost, life-saving treatments for very rare genetic conditions where the medications&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;(1) have a proven therapeutic efficacy,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;(2) are able to substantially extend a patient's lifespan and maintain quality of life as a direct consequence of its use, and&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;(3) be reasonably priced as when compared to its price in other countries.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Rare diseases with onset in childhood are prioritised initially as patients with these conditions can often go on to lead full and meaningful lives if they are diagnosed early in the course of their disease and receive the required treatment promptly.&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Because these treatments tend to be lifelong, the RDF is structured as an endowment fund to ensure that only the interest income generated is used to fund the treatment and the capital sum continues to generate a sustainable stream of income to ensure patients enrolled into the program will have assured support.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Improving coverage of the RDF&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;While welcoming the setup of the RDF, Ms Chan has highlighted that the number of patients, conditions and medicines covered by the RDF is low, potentially leaving some rare disease patients unassisted.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Let me first clarify 3 common misconceptions.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;First, this is not a situation in which eligible patients are not applying for the RDF due to a lack of awareness. In fact, as the costs are high, patients with rare diseases generally seek care in the public sector. We can therefore easily identify patients with rare diseases covered by the RDF and invite those who require financial assistance to apply.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Furthermore, many of the public sector specialists who treat genetic disorders are on the expert panel that advises the RDF Committee on the rare disease medicines that should be considered for coverage by the RDF.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Some patients with rare diseases have insurance coverage or alternative financial means and need not apply for RDF grants.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;11.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;For those in financial need, medical social workers in the public healthcare institution and the patient’s specialist will assist the patient to apply for RDF assistance.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;12.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Second, when we first set up the RDF, it was established that there were up to 2,000 patients with rare diseases in Singapore.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;13.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;However, majority of these patients have conditions where:&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;a. no treatments are available to correct for the genetic deficiency and life expectancy may be limited with poor quality of life, or&lt;br&gt;b. where treatments were relatively low cost and hence can already be supported under current funding sources.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;14.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;We had therefore anticipated there could be up to 15 medicines that needed RDF support based on experiences of equivalent rare disease funds from overseas. In two years, we have covered six medicines.&amp;nbsp; We need to do more, but it is tangible progress in the short time of two years. I would like to thank the RDF Committee for what has been achieved, and for the work that is to come to bring support to more patients.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;15.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Third, Ms Chan has also proposed to list more rare diseases and medicines on the RDF. We should only do so if the rare diseases have effective treatments that can meaningfully extend life expectancy. But adding more medicines does not in itself enable more patients to be helped, especially if the RDF does not have sufficient funds to support more patients for the entire lifetime of their treatment costs.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;16.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In the last financial year, the RDF made grant payouts of around $1 million. Many of the beneficiaries are children. They will grow and increase in body weight, which means that the medication dosage required along with the cost of treatment will go up commensurately. For example, in this financial year, RDF is projecting to make grant payouts of around $1.5 million which is 50% more than the last financial year for the same group of patients.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;17.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In the coming years, the annual sum in grant payouts required would increase significantly just to support these same patients. We have to cater for these increases with age when we decide how many patients the RDF can sustain, in order that the supported patients can be assured that they can continue to afford their medications once they are started on treatment.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;18.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;This is a large sum for a very small number of patients.&amp;nbsp; But that is how much rare disease medicines costs, and why we need all of us – the government and the community – to work together to help this group.&amp;nbsp; Without more donations, it will be very difficult for the RDF to list more medicines or to support new patients.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;More Donations are Critical for More Patients to be Helped&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;19.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;This therefore brings me to the crux of what will allow RDF to help more patients with rare diseases – raising more donations.&amp;nbsp; Ms Chan has also recognised this in her speech.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;20.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;It is not easy raising funds for patients with rare diseases.&amp;nbsp; It was in recognition of this difficulty that the Government decided to match donations 3-to-1, so that every donation dollar is stretched further, and also to help encourage donors to come forward. In addition, all donations to the RDF are also eligible for a generous level of tax deduction at 250%, and the government also funds all administrative costs of the RDF so that donors are assured that every cent of their donation goes to the patients. This also applies to all donations made by corporations and family offices.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;21.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Fully aware of the importance of raising more funds, the RDF Committee together with its secretariat at KKH are doubling up their efforts to raise funds. It has and will continue to approach high-net worth individuals, foundations as well as corporate sponsors, as suggested by Ms Chan. It also stands ready to collaborate with organisations to help raise funds for the RDF, as it has done on a few occasions in the past. It is also exploring how it can develop a base of supporters who can reach out to their network to fundraise.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;22.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The RDF Committee will appreciate all the help it can get. If members of this house would like to help raise funds for the RDF, please let me know and I will gladly put you in touch with the RDF Committee.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Identifying More Rare Diseases for Coverage&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;23.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Let me now turn to a few other proposals made in Ms Chan’s speech.&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;24.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;First, Ms Chan proposed to include two specific rare diseases - Neuroblastoma and Krabbe Disease.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;25.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Neuroblastoma is a form of cancer. Treatments for cancer, including Neuroblastoma are not covered under RDF as mainstream financing is available through MediShield Life currently. Those who need further assistance can apply for MediFund.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;26.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As for Krabbe disease, there are unfortunately no treatments available to slow disease progression today, with most patients succumbing by age 2. The current available medicines are for palliative and supportive care only, which would not fulfil the inclusion criteria for RDF of being able to substantially extend a patient’s lifespan. Patients who require additional assistance for palliative care are already supported via mainstream financing schemes such as subsidies and 3M (MediSave, MediShield Life and MediFund).&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;27.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;I would like to assure Ms Chan that the RDF Committee is well advised by the Rare Disease Expert Group on rare disease drugs that should be prioritised for coverage.&amp;nbsp; Currently, the RDF Committee has a pipeline of 5 other medicines for 3 more rare diseases that stand ready to be added to the RDF list, once sufficient funds are raised.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Tapping More on Insurance&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;28.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Ms Chan also suggested going beyond the RDF and leveraging more on insurance. I note that Ms Chan is familiar with the practice among private insurers of not covering pre-existing illnesses.&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;29.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Where coverage of pre-existing illnesses is provided, it comes with loading of the insurance premium, which can be significant. The benefits and premiums of private insurance products, such as Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), are determined by insurers based on their own commercial and actuarial considerations.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;30.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In doing so, insurers have to strike a balance between providing more comprehensive coverage and ensuring the affordability of premiums as well as the sustainability of their insurance fund. As private insurance is optional, the insurers also need to guard against adverse selection that can affect sustainability.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;31.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Ms Chan may, however, be pleased to know that some insurance products such as IPs do not set exclusions for rare diseases, unless these are pre-existing conditions. In addition, our universal national medical insurance, MediShield Life, covers all Singaporeans from birth, with no disease exclusions and includes all rare diseases, subject to the relevant claims limit. Where there are claim limits to payouts such that there remains an out-of-pocket payment for the patient, the RDF would consider an application to support this remaining out-of-pocket payment.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Conclusion&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;32.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In conclusion, establishing the RDF was a first step in assisting patients with rare diseases. The task remains ahead of us as a community to muster all the necessary resources and assistance that we all agree is needed for this group of fellow Singaporeans.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;33.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;I would like to thank Ms Chan for calling on both the community and the Government, and even the pharmaceutical companies, to provide stronger support towards patients with rare diseases. I would like to reiterate the Government’s commitment towards supporting these patients with rare diseases. I encourage everyone to donate generously to this cause, so that more can benefit from the RDF.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 12:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:1d6e8a9b-739d-4100-aedc-7ca952cf5d8b</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/106-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-covid-19-infection/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>106 NEW CASES OF LOCALLY TRANSMITTED  COVID-19 INFECTION</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 2 August 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has preliminarily confirmed 106 new cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. 65 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 16 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 25 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 7 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In addition, there are 5 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 3 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 2 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 111 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 10:32:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:0ad3f256-2a5a-456b-9f33-31b7744287c6</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/opening-speech-for-the-second-reading-of-the-dental-registration-(amendment)-bill-by-dr-koh-poh-koon-senior-minister-of-state-ministry-of-health-on-monday-2-august-2021_2August2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>OPENING SPEECH FOR THE SECOND READING OF THE DENTAL REGISTRATION (AMENDMENT) BILL BY DR KOH POH KOON, SENIOR MINISTER OF STATE, MINISTRY OF HEALTH, ON MONDAY 2 AUGUST 2021</title><description>&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;1. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Deputy Speaker, on behalf of the Minister for Health, I beg to move, “That the Bill be now read a second time”.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Introduction and Rationale for the Bill&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;2. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Sir, the practice of dentistry constantly evolves with changes in population demographics as well as advancement in technology and materials associated with dental treatment. With Singapore having one of the world’s fastest ageing populations, one of its challenges is ensuring that the needs of a growing ageing population, including dental care needs, are well provided for.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;The Singapore Dental Council (SDC) ensures that there is a steady supply of dentists each year, to meet the expected demand for dental services. In addition to local graduates from the Faculty of Dentistry of the National University of Singapore, the SDC also registers dental graduates from foreign universities.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;The proportion of foreign-trained dentists in Singapore has risen steadily from 20% (302 out of 1,484 dentists) in 2008 to 36% (900 out of 2,475 dentists) in 2019. Against this backdrop, SDC undertook a review of the process for foreign-trained dental graduates to practise in Singapore, to ensure that they meet the same high competency standards as locally trained dental graduates.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;SDC assessed that 2 measures are needed to achieve this objective:&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;a. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt; text-align: left;"&gt;First, the Dental Registration Act (DRA) will be amended by this Bill to require that foreign-trained dental graduates must pass a qualifying examination to be eligible for conditional registration; and&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;b. &amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt; text-align: left;"&gt;Second, the DRA Schedule will be revised, to list the foreign universities whose dental degree holders are automatically eligible to take the qualifying examination.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;6. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; This Bill gives effect to the first measure, relating to the qualifying examination, which I will explain in more detail now. The second measure, which I will touch on briefly later, will be effected by way of subsidiary legislation.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Qualifying Examination for Foreign-Trained Dental Graduates to be Eligible for Conditional Registration&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;7. &amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;Under the current DRA, dental&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;graduates from foreign universities looking to practise in Singapore will typically have to apply for conditional registration first. This means that they have to complete a period of supervised work (usually around 2 years) and be assessed to be competent, before they can apply to be fully registered dentists.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;For the purposes of an application for conditional registration, the SDC recognises dental degrees from universities in Australia, Canada, the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, New Zealand, the Republic of Ireland, the United Kingdom and the United States of America, which are listed in the Schedule of the DRA. If an applicant has a degree in dentistry from a foreign university listed in the Schedule, and also meets the other prevailing criteria for conditional registration, the SDC may grant the applicant conditional registration. These criteria do not currently include a requirement to pass a qualifying examination.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;The SDC may also grant conditional registration to applicants who have degrees in dentistry from other foreign universities not listed in the Schedule. The SDC evaluates such applications on a case-by-case basis and may require that such applicants pass an examination, to ascertain that they have the minimum skills and knowledge to practise and treat patients safely and competently in our local context.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Clause 4 of the Bill amends section 14A of the DRA to introduce a requirement that foreign-trained dental graduates must take and pass a qualifying examination to be eligible for conditional registration. This qualifying examination, which is currently already taken by foreign-trained dental graduates who do not have dentistry degrees in the Schedule, is administered by the NUS Faculty of Dentistry and overseen by SDC. It assesses a dental graduate’s clinical knowledge and procedural skills which are fundamental to the practice of dentistry. This is similar in scope and benchmarked to the standards of the final-year examination of the NUS Faculty of Dentistry. &amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;11. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Section 14A when amended will make it a requirement for foreign dental graduates, regardless of whether their qualifications are contained in the DRA Schedule, to pass a qualifying examination to be eligible for conditional registration.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;12. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Foreign graduates who have a degree in dentistry listed in the DRA Schedule will automatically be eligible to take the qualifying examination. Those not listed in the DRA Schedule are not automatically eligible to take the qualifying examination, but the SDC may permit them to do so on a case-by-case basis if the circumstances set out in section 14A(2) apply. The treatment of foreign graduates with degrees in dentistry not listed in the DRA Schedule will not be so different from that under the current DRA in that they already have to pass an examination to be eligible for conditional registration.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;13. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;This amendment will ensure that the competency standards of&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;foreign dental graduates who are granted conditional registration in Singapore, whether or not their degrees are listed in the DRA Schedule, are aligned with those of dental graduates who have a Singapore degree (which means someone who has obtained a degree in dentistry from NUS).&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;14. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;This new requirement of a qualifying examination will also ensure that foreign dental graduates are familiar with the requirements for clinical practice here in Singapore. For example, the local dental curriculum has in recent times sharpened its focus on core clinical general dentistry skills, and more emphasis has been placed on geriatric dentistry considering the trends in Singapore’s demographics.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;15. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Under the current DRA, any foreign dental graduate with a degree listed in the Schedule is entitled to be registered as a dentist with conditional registration, if he has secured employment with a local dental practice. With the proposed amendment, the qualifying examination will&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;be applicable to graduates with degrees listed in the Schedule as well.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;16. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;To be clear, there is no change to the regime for dental graduates with a Singapore degree. They continue to be eligible to apply for full registration directly. There is no requirement of a qualifying examination for local-trained dental graduates.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Revision of the DRA Schedule&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;17. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;I now move on to the second measure which we will be implementing to ensure the continued quality of foreign-trained dental graduates who practise in Singapore.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;18. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;This will be a revision of the DRA Schedule, which contains the list of foreign degrees in dentistry that are recognised by the Singapore Dental Council for the purposes of conditional registration. This list is curated based on a review of dentistry degrees from foreign universities which the SDC deems&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;em style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;prima facie&lt;/em&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;to meet the standards for practice in Singapore, subject to the individual dental graduate’s proof of his skills, knowledge and competencies through the qualifying examination.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;19. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;As mentioned earlier, foreign dental graduates who have a degree listed in the DRA Schedule will automatically be eligible to take the qualifying examination, unlike the foreign graduates with degrees not listed in the Schedule. Alongside these amendments introduced by the Bill, we will also be revising the Schedule to ensure that the list continues to reflect&amp;nbsp;degrees in dentistry from foreign universities that give their holders this automatic eligibility to take the qualifying examination. The last revision of the Schedule was in 2008, and a review is timely to ensure the continued quality of foreign-trained dental graduates who practise as dentists in Singapore.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;20. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;This revision will be done by way of subsidiary legislation and is not part of the Bill. But I have highlighted this as it complements the introduction of the mandatory qualifying examination that foreign-trained dental graduates must pass to be eligible for conditional registration.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;21. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There will be a transitional period after the revision of the Schedule, where qualifications in the current Schedule will continue to be recognised, and their holders (as well as students who are already enrolled or have secured places in courses leading to such qualifications) may apply for conditional registration under the DRA.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Other Amendments to the DRA&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;22. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;The Bill also makes a number of miscellaneous amendments, which are to provide for payment of penalties and composition sums into the Consolidated Fund, as well as for better administration of the Act.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial; text-align: left;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Conclusion&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;23. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill will ensure the continued quality of foreign-trained dental graduates, and that their clinical skills and competencies are aligned with those of locally-trained dental graduates, so that they can effectively meet the dental needs of our population.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;24. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;Once passed, MOH and SDC will work closely with the dental community and other stakeholders to implement and operationalise these amendments. At present, the introduction of the requirement for the qualifying examination is planned for 1 January 2029. In the coming months, SDC will engage dental students who will be affected by these changes, to ensure that they understand the new requirements and to address any concerns they may have.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;25. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt;"&gt;I seek Members’ support for this Bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I beg to move.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 10:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:80ed6286-605b-465e-aa8c-9102dabb4451</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/amendments-to-dental-registration-act_2August2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>AMENDMENTS TO DENTAL REGISTRATION ACT</title><description>&lt;p style="margin-left: 0cm; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The Ministry of Health (MOH), through the Singapore Dental Council (SDC), will introduce new measures to ensure the continued high quality of foreign-trained dental graduates seeking to practise in Singapore.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px; text-align: left;"&gt;The new measures are being introduced as the SDC had observed a high degree of variability in overseas clinical practices and the dental curriculum of overseas universities. To ensure that the quality and competencies of foreign-trained dental graduates who are eligible to register and practise in Singapore remain high, the standards of the mandatory Qualifying Examination (QE) will be benchmarked to the final-year dental professional examination taken by graduates of the National University of Singapore’s Faculty of Dentistry.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="text-align: left; font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Qualifying Examination&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;3. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Presently, foreign-trained dental graduates with dentistry degrees listed in the Schedule of the&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Dental Registration Act (DRA)&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;can apply for conditional registration to practise in Singapore as long as they fulfill the requirement of securing employment with a local dental clinic or healthcare institution, subject to other requirements under the DRA. Foreign-trained dental graduates&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;with basic dental qualifications not listed in the Schedule are similarly required to secure employment with a local dental clinic or healthcare institution. In addition, for this latter group, the SDC also mandates that they pass an examination to demonstrate the requisite knowledge and skills necessary for conditional registration as a dentist.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px; text-align: left;"&gt;From 2029, foreign-trained dentists are required to demonstrate that they have the requisite clinical knowledge and procedural skills to practise dentistry in Singapore by taking and passing a QE, before they are eligible for conditional registration. Passing the QE will grant eligibility for conditional registration, the usual route by which most foreign-trained dental graduates are first registered in Singapore. The Dental Registration (Amendment) Bill passed in Parliament today will give effect to this requirement, irrespective of the graduate’s nationality.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px; text-align: left;"&gt;5. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The new QE requirement will be effective from&amp;nbsp;1 January 2029. This means that students who are currently enrolled in, or have secured places in dentistry degree programmes and would graduate before 1 January 2029, as well as foreign-trained dental graduates who already hold dental qualifications will not be affected by this change. They will be considered for conditional registration if they fulfil the requirements under the current DRA and until the measures takes effect from 1 January 2029.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;Revision of Registrable Overseas Basic Dental Qualifications&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;6. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;The list of dentistry degrees in the Schedule to the&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;DRA&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;will be revised&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;. Holders of&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;dentistry degrees&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;under the revised list will be automatically eligible to take the QE following the amendments to the DRA, whereas holders of qualifications not under the revised list will have to apply for permission to take the QE&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;. The revision to the Schedule to the DRA will be done through subsidiary legislation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;I&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;n line with the objective of ensuring the continued high quality of foreign-trained dental graduates, the SDC has reviewed the Schedule and will reduce the number of overseas dental schools and universities in the Schedule from the current 89 to 62. Those to be removed are schools from which the SDC had received no applications for registration over the past 12 years.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;The SDC will make available the revised Schedule by end 2021. The Schedule will come into effect in 2029. Students who have secured places, or are enrolled in the affected overseas dental schools or universities will not be impacted. They will still be able to apply to take the QE, and their applications will be considered on a case-by-case basis. The revised Schedule will apply to students who graduate from their studies on or after 1 January 2029.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;MOH and SDC will continue to review the regulatory policies and practices in place to&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;ensure high standards of professional competence by all registered dental practitioners.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial;"&gt;2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 10:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:151b4035-8bd0-4f18-8479-dc85b68550bf</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/no-prior-appointment-needed-at-moderna-vaccination-centres/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>NO PRIOR APPOINTMENT NEEDED AT MODERNA VACCINATION CENTRES </title><description>&lt;p&gt;We have made good progress in our national COVID-19 vaccination programme thus far. As of 31 July 2021, we have administered around 7.5 million doses of COVID-19 vaccine. Around 4.3 million individuals have received at least the first dose of the vaccine, of whom about 3.3 million have completed the full vaccination regimen. This means about 61% of Singapore residents have completed the full vaccination regimen.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Thus far, 83% of those aged 60 and above, 88% of those aged 45 to 59, 87% of those aged 40 to 44, and 83% of those aged 12 to 39 years of age, have received at least one dose of COVID-19 vaccine or booked their appointments.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Since mid-July, seniors aged 60 and above have been allowed to walk into any vaccination centre, polyclinic or participating Public Health Preparedness Clinic to receive their vaccination without an appointment. To further increase the convenience for all to get vaccinated, from 2 August 2021, all Singaporeans, Permanent Residents, and Long-Term Pass holders aged 18 years old and above who have not yet come forward for their first dose will be able to walk-in to any of our 11 community vaccination centres offering the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine without a prior appointment. These vaccination centres are at:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Buona Vista Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Hong Kah North Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Kebun Baru Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Kolam Ayer Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Marsiling Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Potong Pasir Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Punggol 21 Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Radin Mas Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Tampines East Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Woodlands Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Yew Tee Community Club&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;p&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Vaccination remains a key enabler in our fight against COVID-19. Its ability to help Singapore reopen safely can only be felt when we can collectively achieve a high level of population coverage for vaccination. We urge all who are eligible to be vaccinated. Individuals can also book appointments at www.vaccine.gov.sg to get vaccinated.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;2 AUGUST 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 06:52:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:360c3265-6afd-4fcf-8557-7f6c0025c757</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-local-covid-19-situation-(1-aug-2021)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>UPDATE ON LOCAL COVID-19 SITUATION (1 Aug 2021)</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 1 August 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed and verified that there are 113 cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection. 70 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 5 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 38 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 7 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are 8 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 7 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;In total, there are 121 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 1: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Local Unlinked Cases and Linked Cases by Already Quarantined/Detected through Surveillance&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure01_1aug.png?sfvrsn=9747c91f_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure01_1aug.png?sfvrsn=9747c91f_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure01_1Aug" title="Figure01_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Progress of national vaccination programme&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 31 July 2021, 61% of our population has completed their full regimen/ received two doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme, and 77% has received at least one dose. In total, we have administered a total of 7,576,612 doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme, covering 4,307,602 individuals, with 3,391,799 individuals having completed the full vaccination regimen. In addition, 104,061 doses of Sinovac vaccines have been administered as of 31 July 2021, covering 74,121 individuals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 2: &lt;/strong&gt;Percentage of Total Population who Received At Least First Dose&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt; and Completed Full Regimen&lt;sup&gt;3&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure02_1aug.png?sfvrsn=54deed11_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure02_1aug.png?sfvrsn=54deed11_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure02_1Aug" title="Figure02_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 3: &lt;/strong&gt;Percentage of Vaccinated Individuals who Received At Least First Dose by Age Group&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure03_1aug.png?sfvrsn=f354510b_0"&gt;&lt;img data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 5: &lt;/strong&gt;Total number of doses administered&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure05_1aug.png?sfvrsn=104ad77b_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure05_1aug.png?sfvrsn=104ad77b_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure05_1Aug" title="Figure05_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Condition of confirmed cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;590 cases are currently warded in hospital.&amp;nbsp; Most are well and under observation. There are currently 35 cases of serious illness requiring oxygen supplementation, and 8 in critical condition in the intensive care unit (ICU). 4 amongst these 43 cases are fully vaccinated. Of these, 3 require oxygen supplementation while 1 requires ICU care as they have underlying medical conditions. 29 seniors above 60 years, of whom 26 are completely unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, have fallen very ill.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 6: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure06_1aug.png?sfvrsn=fad019f4_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure06_1aug.png?sfvrsn=fad019f4_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure06_1Aug" title="Figure06_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 7: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure07_1aug.png?sfvrsn=574b1844_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure07_1aug.png?sfvrsn=574b1844_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure07_1Aug" title="Figure07_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There is continuing evidence that vaccination helps to prevent serious disease when one gets infected. Over the last 28 days, 55 local cases required oxygen supplementation, were admitted to ICU or passed away. 33 are unvaccinated, 18 are partially vaccinated and 4 are fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 8:&lt;/strong&gt; Local Cases in the Last 28 Days by Vaccination Status &amp;amp; Severity of Condition&lt;sup&gt;4&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure08_1aug.png?sfvrsn=60b13ed5_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure08_1aug.png?sfvrsn=60b13ed5_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure08_1Aug" title="Figure08_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 9: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;by Vaccination Status&lt;sup&gt;4&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure09_1aug.png?sfvrsn=cdb9a50c_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure09_1aug.png?sfvrsn=cdb9a50c_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure09_1Aug" title="Figure09_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for local cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Overall, the number of new cases in the community has decreased from 1,056 cases in the week before to 862 cases in the past week. We are likely to continue to see high number of cases in the coming days as we step up efforts to detect them to contain their spread in the community. The number of unlinked cases in the community has increased from 119 cases in the week before to 282 cases in the past week. The 7-day moving average number of all linked community cases and all unlinked community cases are 82.9 and 40.3 respectively.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 10: &lt;/strong&gt;7 Day Moving Average Number of Community Unlinked and Linked Cases&lt;sup&gt;5&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure10_1aug.png?sfvrsn=8f3be42e_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure10_1aug.png?sfvrsn=8f3be42e_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure10_1Aug" title="Figure10_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Figure 11: &lt;/strong&gt;Local Cases in the Last 14 Days by Age Group and Vaccination Status&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure11_1aug.png?sfvrsn=12a24988_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure11_1aug.png?sfvrsn=12a24988_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure11_1Aug" title="Figure11_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for imported cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are a total of 8 imported cases today. 1 was detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 7 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 12:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Imported Cases by Detected Upon Arrival/Detected during SHN or Isolation&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure12_1aug.png?sfvrsn=14372e2e_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure12_1aug.png?sfvrsn=14372e2e_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure12_1Aug" title="Figure12_1Aug" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Active clusters under monitoring&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are 10 new clusters today. In total, there are currently 83 active clusters, ranging between 3 and 1,045 infections.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 13: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active
