text-align: left;"&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div style="padding: 0in 0in 1pt; border-top: none; border-right: none; border-bottom-width: 1pt; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left: none;"&gt; &lt;p style="padding: 0in; border: none;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;30 JULY 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;br clear="all"&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"&gt; &lt;div id="ftn1"&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 13px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;[1] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn2"&gt; &lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 13px;"&gt;[2] Fully vaccinated - more than 14 days after completing vaccination regimen (both doses of the vaccine or one dose for recovered individuals). Partially vaccinated – received 1 dose of 2-dose vaccine or COVID-positive within 14 days of completing vaccination regimen.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn3"&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 13px;"&gt;[3] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn4"&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 13px;"&gt;[4] Includes new cases added today.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn5"&gt; &lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 13px;"&gt;[5] Based on National Immunisation Registry data. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div id="ftn6"&gt; &lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 13px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;[6] Full regimen refers to individuals who have received both doses of the vaccine or one dose for vaccinated recovered individuals.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 30 Jul 2021 15:55:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:1fb62816-457b-44f5-9a78-0f9584b81369</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/131-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-covid-19-infection_30_July_2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>131 New Cases of Locally Transmitted COVID-19 Infection</title><description>&lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;span style="color: black;"&gt;1.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 30 July 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has preliminarily confirmed 131 new &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;span&gt;cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection, of which 28 are linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and 1 belongs to the KTV cluster.&amp;nbsp;Of the 131 cases today, 64 are &lt;span class="bumpedfont15"&gt;linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 15 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 52 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases is 1 senior above 70 years who is partially vaccinated, and is at risk of serious illness. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p style="text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;span&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;In addition, there are 8 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated &lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;upon arrival in Singapore&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="text-align: left; font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;. 2 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 6 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;In total, there are 139 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 16px;"&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div style="padding: 0in 0in 1pt; border-top: none; border-right: none; border-bottom-width: 1pt; border-bottom-style: solid; border-left: none;"&gt; &lt;p style="padding: 0in; border: none;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;30 JULY 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;p style="padding: 0in; border: none;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 30 Jul 2021 09:21:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:0ea351e2-2a96-48e5-a4e0-db94fc46b6f6</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/opening-address-by-dr-janil-puthucheary-senior-minister-of-state-ministry-of-communications-and-information-ministry-of-health-at-the-institute-of-mental-health-nurses-day-celebration/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>OPENING ADDRESS BY DR JANIL PUTHUCHEARY, SENIOR MINISTER OF STATE, MINISTRY OF COMMUNICATIONS AND INFORMATION &amp; MINISTRY OF HEALTH, AT THE INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH NURSES’ DAY CELEBRATION</title><description>Associate Professor Daniel Fung, Chief Executive Officer, IMH&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Ms Paulin Koh, Chief Nursing Officer, MOH&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Mr Yong Keng Kwang, Group Chief Nurse, NHG&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Ms Samantha Ong, Chief Nurse, IMH&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;All Nurses&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Fellow healthcare colleagues&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Good afternoon and Happy Nurses’ Day to all nurses here. It is my privilege to celebrate this special occasion with IMH’s frontline warriors today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;COVID-19 EFFORTS&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; 2021 continues to be a challenging year, with the COVID-19 pandemic still raging around the world, and clusters still active in Singapore. Many aspects of our lives have been impacted.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, our psychiatric nurses have been at the forefront of protecting patients from the virus. You have faced many challenges, from redesigning patient flow, to stratifying risks of patients being admitted with COVID-19, and quickly isolating any patients with signs of the infection. All these while maintaining a high patient load, stepping up infection control measures and ensuring safe management measures.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Last year, when there was a call for help with the national COVID-19 operations, more than 300 IMH nurses came forward and were deployed to perform intensive swab testing in the community. This year, you stood up yet again to administer COVID-19 vaccination shots for your colleagues and long-stay patients. Thank you for playing such critical roles in our fight against the pandemic.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;NEW MODEL OF CARE&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Amidst all these, I am happy to hear that IMH is transitioning to a recovery model of care, advocating for a holistic, person-centred approach to mental health care. The wards are being refurbished and redesigned to offer not just a better physical space but a more conducive environment where more personalised recovery programmes can be carried out. Nurses will play a major role in this new care paradigm and I know you will all continue to do your best to care for your patients, instil hope and empower them to live well, despite their conditions.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;EVOLVING ROLE OF NURSES&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; IMH is also setting up a new Short Stay Unit, targeted at helping patients who require specialised crisis care. The multidisciplinary team in this unit will be led by nurses equipped with transdisciplinary skills, and I commend this initiative to offer new opportunities for nurses to play a bigger role in patient care. This is in line with MOH’s emphasis to continue to enhance the role of nurses. The scope of work and training will be broadened to allow nurses to play a wider role in providing care and improving the health of our population. For example, for nurses who aspire to be Advanced Practice Nurses (APNs), we will enhance transdisciplinary training to build complementary skillsets through the new integrated APN internship programme. There are now 11 APNs in IMH who have graduated from the National Collaborative Prescribing Programme since its inception in 2018. This has equipped the APNs to include prescribing as part of their approach to patient’s care for a more timely and comprehensive management.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Every year, MOH gives out the Nurses’ Merit Award to deserving nurses who have demonstrated noteworthy and exceptional performance, participated in professional development and contributed to raising the standards of the nursing profession. One of this year’s awardees from IMH is Covering Senior Nurse Manager Zheng He.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Zheng He works in a remand ward and looks after forensic patients and those in civil detention under the Mental Health Care &amp;amp; Treatment Act, whom we call formalised patients. Traditionally, patients in this ward are monitored more closely so they typically do not get the opportunity to participate in outdoor activities. To cheer these patients up, he collaborated with an Activity Nurse, an APN and Occupational Therapists to design a nurse-led activity programme to promote the well-being and enhance the cognitive functions of this group of patients. Zheng He also introduced a baking programme to teach patients how to bake cookies, which would later be served to other patients. This baking activity has helped staff to build rapport with their patients, indirectly allowing staff to better understand their patients’ care needs. I hope your efforts will continue to inspire your patients, and fellow nurses.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate all winners of IMH’s Awards and MOH’s Nurses’ Merit Award. Excellent work!&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;CLOSING&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In closing, I want to thank all of you once again for your dedication and outstanding contributions to Singapore’s healthcare system. You have shown great fortitude and adaptability in tackling the many changes you face. I wish everyone an enjoyable celebration. Thank you.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 30 Jul 2021 07:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:e699d833-a144-46d1-9820-062f998c8fe2</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/keynote-address-by-ms-rahayu-mahzam-parliamentary-secretary-ministry-of-communications-and-information-and-ministry-of-health-at-the-child-evidence-to-policy-and-practice-webinar-series/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>KEYNOTE ADDRESS BY MS RAHAYU MAHZAM, PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARY, MINISTRY OF COMMUNICATIONS AND INFORMATION AND MINISTRY OF HEALTH, AT THE CHILD EVIDENCE TO POLICY AND PRACTICE WEBINAR SERIES</title><description>Mr Hsieh Fu Hua,&lt;br&gt;Chairman, NUS Board of Trustees, NUS &amp;amp; NUHS&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Prof Yeoh Khay Guan,&lt;br&gt;Chief Executive, NUHS&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Mr Lawrence Lien,&lt;br&gt;Chairman, Lien Foundation&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Mr Lee Poh Wah,&lt;br&gt;CEO, Lien Foundation&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Mr Peter Hodgson,&lt;br&gt;Chair, Centre for Evidence and Implementation (CEI)&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Professor Johan Eriksson,&lt;br&gt;Deputy Executive Director, Singapore Institute for Clinical Sciences (SICS)&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Esteemed speakers and Panellists,&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Distinguished Participants,&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Ladies and gentlemen,&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Good morning. I am delighted to join you this morning at the inaugural Evidence to Policy and Practice Webinar Series, in conjunction with the launch of the Centre for Holistic Initiatives for Learning and Development, or in short, CHILD. It is my honour to be in the presence of many established academics and practitioners in the area of early childhood development.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Child and Maternal Health and Well-being Strategy and Taskforce&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As a mother with a young child, today’s topic is close to my heart. As parents, our greatest concern is how we can help our children grow up well and achieve their aspirations. We believe that every child deserves the best start in life and be given the opportunity to develop well throughout his life so as to reach his full potential. To enable this, we need to extend more support to the family, especially the mother, because her health and well-being exert a significant influence on her child’s development, even before her child is born. We also cannot undermine the influence&amp;nbsp; of the family and parenting practices on the trajectory of a child’s development.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; To this end, we have set up an inter-agency Taskforce earlier this year to develop a national Child and Maternal Health and Well-being Strategy that will focus on supporting women and their children to attain good health and well-being, leading to a healthier next generation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; This will be a five-year strategy, adopting a life-course approach – starting as early as pre-conception to adolescents aged 18 years old. As the needs of a child and his family extend beyond healthcare, we have brought together various agencies, including those from the education and social domains, to jointly address cross-cutting issues that require close collaboration across agencies.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We recognise that there could be many aspects of child and maternal health and well-being that we could focus on. We are therefore prioritising key areas with clear measurable health, social and education outcomes for our young that would benefit multiple generations.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Let me elaborate. I would broadly group the Taskforce’s efforts into three key thrusts:&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;a.&amp;nbsp; First, we are focusing on translating evidence-based findings into policies and programmes to address risk factors, and going further upstream on preventive health efforts for women and children. This is where platforms like today’s could be leveraged to support the efforts.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;b.&amp;nbsp; A few months ago, we had a very fruitful session, learning from Prof Chong and his team on the GUSTO findings. We explored how some of these evidence-based findings could be translated into programmes to address the specific needs of the child at different life stages and developmental milestones. One of the topics we discussed was on screen time for young children and how early screen and TV viewing could impact the cognitive development of a child. This is also the focus of today’s webinar series and I look forward to further discussions later.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;c.&amp;nbsp; Second, we are reviewing our service delivery for children and their families.&amp;nbsp; We want to better integrate our services across the domains to deliver holistic and seamless care to children and their families. By wrapping services around the mother-child dyad, we hope to&amp;nbsp; make it easier for families to access services. This would also help us to provide better support for mothers who may otherwise neglect their own healthcare needs.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;d. In the last few months, I had the privilege of joining colleagues from the health, social and education domains in several conversations with our frontline officers to understand their key challenges in service delivery and to jointly identify opportunities, where we could further strengthen collaboration across the health-social-education domains. These had been insightful sessions where issues and suggestions raised helped us to crystalise our thinking further as we work towards extending more integrated and holistic support to the mother and child.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;e. Third, we are reviewing our approaches to engage stakeholders and the public and to hear what matters most to them. A big part of this effort that I am leading involves public education to raise awareness and communicate our key messages to parents, grandparents, educators, caregivers and the general public, to shape positive behaviours. We will continue to engage these stakeholders to understand their concerns, common pain points and aspirations in order to ensure that our messages and support to them are relevant.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Launch of CHILD and its significance to support the Strategy&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; To achieve the desired health outcomes at the individual and population level, it is important for the recommendations of the Taskforce and the Strategy to be grounded on sound scientific basis.&amp;nbsp; While we have identified research as one of the key enablers for the Child and Maternal Health and Well-being Strategy, I would like to highlight that the translation of these scientific research and evidence-based findings into policies and programme interventions would be the key to making a real difference to individuals..&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; I am heartened to know that CHILD would focus on doing this, and its launch today signifies the start of more conversations to consider how research could better inform policies and programmes to benefit more children and their families. Let me offer three suggestions where I think research could help to sharpen our efforts.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Firstly, we need a good basis for policy making and programme intervention. Evidence-based findings from robust research and analysis could better inform our policies and help refine our recommendations and interventions to make them relevant and effective. For example, through distilling evidence-based findings, we could design better screening tools to accurately and reliably detect and identify at-risk children so that targeted interventions or relevant services could be provided to meet their needs holistically.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Secondly, we need to better communicate scientific research findings into clear, salient messages easily understood by&amp;nbsp; key stakeholders, like parents and educators who are non-researchers. For example, parents need to understand the key implications of screen-time on their child’s cognitive development and the evidence-based guidance that they could take reference from. We need to make sure that such messages and guidance which originate from rigorous research are simple and comprehensible.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;11.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Thirdly, it is important to keep our translation of research and knowledge current; we need to communicate such messages faster to key stakeholders to address any information lag. This would enable interventions to start as early as possible to benefit children and their families.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;12.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Take screen time as an example. Like myself, some of us sitting here could be parents of young children, and we may have some questions about the negative impact of screen time on young children. The GUSTO study had found that exposure to passive viewing screen time below the age of 18 months is associated with poor cognitive and language outcomes. The duration of infant television viewing at one year of age was also negatively associated with subsequent cognitive and language skills at four and a half years of age. This remains significant even after accounting for perinatal, child and family circumstances. In addition, screen time between one and one and a half years has been associated with a variety of social skills deficits commonly found in children on the autism spectrum. Such a vital piece of evidence would certainly influence and guide how we provide care for our children.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;13.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; The setting up of CHILD is a timely and significant boost to enable the process of translating evidence-based findings into policies and programmes in early childhood development. With its intent to engage and bring together key local stakeholders from both the public and private sector who are interested in the emotional, cognitive, and social well-being of children from conception to primary school years, we welcome the further conversations that CHILD could generate and contribute towards a healthier next generation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Closing&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;14.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In closing, I would like to congratulate NUS Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, Professor Chong Yap Seng and the team at CHILD on its launch. Thank you and have a fruitful webinar.&lt;br&gt;</description><pubDate>Fri, 30 Jul 2021 03:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:93bafefe-0dae-4bbf-897f-a10b69425bf3</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-local-covid-19-situation-(29-july)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Update On Local COVID-19 Situation (29 July)</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt; As of 29 July 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH)&amp;nbsp;has confirmed&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"&gt;and verified&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;that&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"&gt;there are 129&amp;nbsp;cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection, of which 30 are linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and 2 belong to the KTV cluster.&amp;nbsp;Of the 129 cases today, 68 are&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class="m_-5533908518239507566bumpedfont15" style="font-size: 16px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"&gt;linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 11 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 50 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 4 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class="m_-5533908518239507566bumpedfont15" style="font-size: 16px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34);"&gt;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 10pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span class="m_-5533908518239507566bumpedfont15" style=""&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 10pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span class="m_-5533908518239507566bumpedfont15"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;There are 4 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore.&amp;nbsp;3 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 1 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 10pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;3.&lt;span style="font-stretch: normal;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;In total, there are 133 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Figure 1:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;Number of Community Unlinked Cases, and Linked Cases by Already Quarantined/ Detected through Surveillance, and Dormitory Resident Cases&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-1-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=8fcbeff9_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-1-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=8fcbeff9_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 1. (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 1. (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(47, 84, 150); margin: 0in; font-size: 13pt; font-weight: normal;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="color: windowtext;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(47, 84, 150); margin: 0in; font-size: 13pt; font-weight: normal;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="color: windowtext;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(47, 84, 150); margin: 0in; font-size: 13pt; font-weight: normal;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="color: windowtext;"&gt;Condition of confirmed cases&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;572 cases are currently warded in hospital.&amp;nbsp; Most are well and under observation. There are currently 30 cases of serious illness requiring oxygen supplementation, and 3 in critical condition in the intensive care unit (ICU). 1 amongst these 33 cases is fully vaccinated, but requires ICU care as she has underlying medical conditions. 24 seniors above 60 years, of whom 23 are completely unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, have fallen very ill.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 2:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;Number of Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-2-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=d7c46fe2_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-2-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=d7c46fe2_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 2. (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 2. Over the last 28 days, 39 local cases required oxygen supplementation, were admitted to ICU or passed away. 23 are unvaccinated, 15 are partially vaccinated and 1 is fully vaccinated.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px 0px 8pt; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Figure 4:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;Local Cases in the Last 28 Days by Vaccination Status &amp;amp; Severity of Condition&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px 0px 8pt; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px 0px 8pt; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-4-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=3c1750c3_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-4-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=3c1750c3_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 4 (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 4 (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Figure 5:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;by Vaccination Status&lt;/span&gt;&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px 0px 8pt; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-5-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=6a04c92b_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-5-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=6a04c92b_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 5. (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 5. (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Summary of trends for local cases&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;a name="m_-5533908518239507566__Hlk54809989"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Overall,&amp;nbsp;the number of new cases in the community has decreased from 884 cases in the week before to 881 cases in the past week. We are likely to continue to see high number of cases in the coming days as we step up efforts to detect them to contain their spread in the community. The number of unlinked cases in the community has increased from 64 cases in the week before to 238 cases in the past week.&amp;nbsp;The 7-day moving average number of all linked community cases and all unlinked community cases are 91.9 and 34.0 respectively.&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0px; font-size: small;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;br&gt;Figure 6:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;7 Day Moving Average Number of Community Unlinked and Linked Cases&lt;sup&gt;3&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-6-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=b90f23_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-6-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=b90f23_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 6. (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 6. dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;Case 64388&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;0&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;3&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;105 Henderson Crescent&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;0&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;22&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;Changi General Hospital&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;0&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;20&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;* Please refer to &lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider5/pressroom/press-releases/annex-a-29-jul.pdf?sfvrsn=13ae6512_0" title="Annex A"&gt;Annex A&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;for the affected markets and food centres.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span id="docs-internal-guid-e94cb47e-7fff-d62a-f558-3724320f9cde" style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Collection of ART self-test kits for visitors to selected markets and food centres&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;MOH is investigating cases of COVID-19 infection involving markets and food centres which are likely seeded by fishmongers who visited Jurong Fishery Port to collect their stock and sell at the markets and food centres. As an added layer of ringfencing to help to identify cases and prevent further transmission, MOH is working with the People’s Association to distribute antigen rapid test (ART) self-test kits to individuals who had visited selected markets and food centres in the last 14 days, such as residents living in the vicinity of these centres. The collection will run from 30 to 31 July 2021 at Residents’ Committee Centres in the vicinity of the following locations:&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li dir="ltr" aria-level="1"&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" role="presentation"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;Mayflower Market &amp;amp; Food Centre (162 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 4); and&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li dir="ltr" aria-level="1"&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr" role="presentation"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;Redhill Market (79 Redhill Lane).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Eligible persons are strongly encouraged to collect and perform self-testing using these ART kits. Please refer to &lt;a href="https://www.gowhere.gov.sg/art"&gt;https://www.gowhere.gov.sg/art&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;to check on the nearest Residents’ Committee Centre for self-collection.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Progress of national vaccination programme&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;11.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 28 July 2021, we have administered a total of 7,365,873 doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme. The total number of doses administered was 7,365,873, covering 4,278,760 individuals. 3,208,556 individuals have completed the full vaccination regimen, consisting of 121,443 recovered persons who received at least one dose and 3,087,113 who received their second dose. In addition, 95,029 doses of Sinovac vaccines have been administered as of 28 July 2021, covering 71,810 individuals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 12:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; Progress of National Vaccination Programme&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-12-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=61f8184d_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-12-(29-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=61f8184d_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 12. (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 12. (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Figure 13:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Total Population who Received At Least First Dose&lt;sup&gt;5&lt;/sup&gt; and Completed Full Regimen&lt;sup&gt;6&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-13-(29-jul)2e0019b7a7d54c78a20c4dce3656e611.png?sfvrsn=c4d555de_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-13-(29-jul)2e0019b7a7d54c78a20c4dce3656e611.png?sfvrsn=c4d555de_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 13 (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 13 (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 14:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Vaccinated Individuals who Received At Least First Dose by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-14-(29-jul).png?sfvrsn=c60d300_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-14-(29-jul).png?sfvrsn=c60d300_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 14. (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 14. (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 15: &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;Percentage of Individuals who Completed Full Regimen of COVID-19 Vaccine by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-15-(29-jul).png?sfvrsn=4ac4fccd_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-15-(29-jul).png?sfvrsn=4ac4fccd_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 15 (29 Jul)" title="Fig. 15 (29 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;12.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Please refer to MOH’s daily Situation Report (&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report"&gt;www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report&lt;/a&gt;) for details.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;29 JULY 2021&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;br&gt;[1] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;br&gt;[2] Fully vaccinated - more than 14 days after completing vaccination regimen (both doses of the vaccine or one dose for recovered individuals). Partially vaccinated – received 1 dose of 2-dose vaccine or COVID-positive within 14 days of completing vaccination regimen.&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;[3] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;br&gt;[4] Includes new cases added today&lt;br&gt;[5] Based on National Immunisation Registry data.&lt;br&gt;[6] Full regimen refers to individuals who have received both doses of the vaccine or one dose for vaccinated recovered individuals.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34); margin: 0in; font-size: 11pt;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 12px;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Thu, 29 Jul 2021 15:59:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:a8886be0-b3dc-4c6a-b345-93ed63c7c5db</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/community-surveillance-testing-at-3-teck-whye-avenue-and-357-yung-an-road_29July2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title> COMMUNITY SURVEILLANCE TESTING AT  3 TECK WHYE AVENUE AND 357 YUNG AN ROAD </title><description>&lt;p class="Default" style="margin: 0cm; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The Ministry of Health (MOH) is investigating likely COVID-19 transmission at 3 Teck Whye Avenue and 357 Yung An Road. So far,&amp;nbsp;seven cases of COVID-19 infection have been detected in four households at&amp;nbsp;3 Teck Whye Avenue. Separately, four cases of COVID-19 infection have been detected in three households at 357 Yung An Road.&amp;nbsp;&lt;span&gt;Epidemiological investigations are ongoing to determine linkages and the source of transmission.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;2. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;In&amp;nbsp;order to uncover community infection cases, MOH&amp;nbsp;will conduct mandatory&amp;nbsp;COVID-19&amp;nbsp;testing for all residents of 3 Teck Whye Avenue and 357 Yung An Road.&amp;nbsp;Testing is optional for those who have tested negative for COVID-19 infection from 25 July onwards.&amp;nbsp;Mandatory testing will be conducted&amp;nbsp;on 30 July 2021 between 9am and 4pm at the void deck of 1 Teck Whye Avenue, and the pavilion between 357 and 359 Yung An Road, respectively.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;3. &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;All residents are to bring along their NRIC for identification purposes.&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="color: rgb(0, 112, 192);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;Leaflets have been distributed and SMS notifications have been sent to the residents to provide them with more information. Residents are reminded to keep to their appointment time. Residents are also advised to monitor their health closely and consult a doctor immediately if they feel unwell. Those who are still awaiting their test results are advised to minimise social interactions as much as possible. They should continue to monitor their health and seek immediate medical attention if they feel unwell.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; text-align: justify;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;span style="font-family: Arial;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;29 JULY 2021&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style="margin: 0cm; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif;"&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description><pubDate>Thu, 29 Jul 2021 11:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:d9c736cb-024b-464d-9be6-0280b3948f1b</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/129-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-covid-19-infection-29-july-2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>129 New Cases of Locally Transmitted COVID-19 Infection</title><description>&lt;span style="font-size: 16px;"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 29 July 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has preliminarily confirmed 129 new cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection, of which 30 are linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and 2 belong to the KTV cluster. Of the 129 cases today, 68 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 11 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 50 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 4 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;In addition, there are 4 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 3 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 1 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 133 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;MINISTRY OF HEALTH&lt;br&gt;29 JULY 2021&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</description><pubDate>Thu, 29 Jul 2021 09:55:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:a4d9ea81-6d77-4c31-9c6d-90e8b2746a1b</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-local-covid-19-situation-(28-july-2021)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>UPDATE ON LOCAL COVID-19 SITUATION (28 JULY 2021)</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 28 July 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed and verified that there are 130 cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection, of which 27 are linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and 2 belong to the KTV cluster. Of the 130 cases today, 61 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 21 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 48 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 3 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are 6 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 2 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 4 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;In total, there are 136 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 1: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Community Unlinked Cases, and Linked Cases by Already Quarantined/ Detected through Surveillance, and Dormitory Resident Cases&lt;sup&gt;[1]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig1(28jul).png?sfvrsn=a632c8c3_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig1(28jul).png?sfvrsn=a632c8c3_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig1(28Jul)" title="Fig1(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Condition of confirmed cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;567 cases are currently warded in hospital.&amp;nbsp; Most are well and under observation. There are currently 23 cases of serious illness requiring oxygen supplementation, and 2 in critical condition in the intensive care unit (ICU). 1 amongst these 25 cases is fully vaccinated, but requires oxygen supplementation as she has underlying medical conditions. 16 seniors above 60 years, of whom 15 are completely unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, have fallen very ill.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 2: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig2(28jul).png?sfvrsn=f8455792_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig2(28jul).png?sfvrsn=f8455792_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig2(28Jul)" title="Fig2(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 3:&lt;/strong&gt; Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig3(28jul).png?sfvrsn=5f2844e6_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig3(28jul).png?sfvrsn=5f2844e6_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig3(28Jul)" title="Fig3(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There is continuing evidence that vaccination helps to prevent serious disease when one gets infected. Over the last 28 days, 31 local cases required oxygen supplementation, were admitted to ICU or passed away. 16 are unvaccinated,13 are partially vaccinated and 1 is fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 4:&lt;/strong&gt; Local Cases in the Last 28 Days by Vaccination Status &amp;amp; Severity of Condition&lt;sup&gt;[2]&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-4-(28-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=cd7eaffe_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig-4-(28-jul).jpg?sfvrsn=cd7eaffe_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig. 4 (28 Jul)" title="Fig. 4 (28 Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 5:&lt;/strong&gt; Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;by Vaccination Status&lt;sup&gt;[2]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig5(28jul).png?sfvrsn=d143dfe7_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig5(28jul).png?sfvrsn=d143dfe7_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig5(28Jul)" title="Fig5(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for local cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Overall, the number of new cases in the community has increased from 765 cases in the week before to 915 cases in the past week. We are likely to continue to see high number of cases in the coming days as we step up efforts to detect them to contain their spread in the community. The number of unlinked cases in the community has also increased from 45 cases in the week before to 217 cases in the past week. The 7-day moving average number of all linked community cases and all unlinked community cases are 99.7 and 31 respectively.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 6:&lt;/strong&gt; 7 Day Moving Average Number of Community Unlinked and Linked Cases&lt;sup&gt;[3]&amp;nbsp;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig6(28jul).png?sfvrsn=eec84685_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig6(28jul).png?sfvrsn=eec84685_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig6(28Jul)" title="Fig6(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 7:&lt;/strong&gt; Community Unlinked and Linked Cases in the Last 14 Days, by Detection Method&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig7(28jul).png?sfvrsn=60b0a891_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig7(28jul).png?sfvrsn=60b0a891_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig7(28Jul)" title="Fig7(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 8: &lt;/strong&gt;Local Cases in the Last 14 Days by Age Group and Vaccination Status&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig8(28jul).png?sfvrsn=6720f441_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig8(28jul).png?sfvrsn=6720f441_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig8(28Jul)" title="Fig8(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for imported cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are a total of 6 imported cases today. 2 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 4 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 9:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Imported Cases by Detected Upon Arrival/&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;Detected during SHN or Isolation&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig9(28jul).png?sfvrsn=a55ca631_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig9(28jul).png?sfvrsn=a55ca631_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig9(28Jul)" title="Fig9(28Jul)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Active clusters under monitoring&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;There are 5 new clusters today. In total, there are currently 44 active clusters, ranging between 3 and 932 infections.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 10:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Active align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 65846&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 65791&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;4&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 65342&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p 65484&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;5&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 65365&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 64735&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;6&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 65231&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;4&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td width="372"&gt;&lt;p&gt;Case 64599&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p
