&lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;8&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;tr&gt; &lt;td width="558"&gt; &lt;p&gt;Case 64642&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;tr&gt; &lt;td width="558"&gt; &lt;p&gt;Case 64388 &lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;tr&gt; &lt;td width="558"&gt; &lt;p&gt;105 Henderson Crescent&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;22&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;tr&gt; &lt;td width="558"&gt; &lt;p&gt;Changi General Hospital&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;20&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;tr&gt; &lt;td width="558"&gt; &lt;p&gt;Case 64478&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;td width="172" valign="top"&gt; &lt;p align="center"&gt;3&lt;/p&gt; &lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt; &lt;div&gt;&lt;br clear="all"&gt; &lt;div id="ftn1"&gt; &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href="file:///C:/Users/Shireen%20YEO%20(MOH)/Downloads/Press%20Release-Confirmed%20cases%2066262%20to%2066404-Draft%2026Jul%202345h%20(Final).docx#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;* Please refer to &lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/docs/librariesprovider5/pressroom/press-releases/annex-a---26-jul-2021.pdf?sfvrsn=358bb9f6_0" title="Annex A"&gt;Annex A&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;for the affected markets and food centres.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Progress of national vaccination programme&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9. As of 25 July 2021, we have administered a total of 7,192,180 doses of COVID-19 vaccines under the national vaccination programme. The total number of doses administered was 7,192,180, covering 4,242,505 individuals.&amp;nbsp; 3,070,092 individuals have completed the full vaccination regimen, consisting of 120,417 recovered persons who received at least one dose and 2,949,675 who received their second dose. In addition, 83,072 doses of Sinovac vaccines have been administered as of 25 July 2021, covering 67,970 individuals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 12:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; Progress of National Vaccination Programme&lt;br&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure12_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=94a671c1_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure12_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=94a671c1_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure12_26jul2021" title="Figure12_26jul2021" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 13:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Total Population who Received At Least First Dose&lt;sup&gt;5&lt;/sup&gt; and Completed Full Regimen&lt;sup&gt;6&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure13_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=e52acb87_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure13_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=e52acb87_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure13_26jul2021" title="Figure13_26jul2021" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 14:&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;Percentage of Vaccinated Individuals who Received At Least First Dose by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure14_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=a57449f1_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure14_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=a57449f1_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure14_26jul2021" title="Figure14_26jul2021" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style="text-decoration: underline;"&gt;Figure 15:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; Percentage of Individuals who Completed Full Regimen of COVID-19 Vaccine by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure15_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=e33e5bca_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/figure15_26jul2021.png?sfvrsn=e33e5bca_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Figure15_26jul2021" title="Figure15_26jul2021" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10. Please refer to MOH’s daily Situation Report (w&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report"&gt;ww.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/situation-report&lt;/a&gt;) for details.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;[1] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;[2] Fully vaccinated - more than 14 days after completing vaccination regimen (both doses of the vaccine or one dose for recovered individuals). Partially vaccinated – received 1 dose of 2-dose vaccine or COVID-positive within 14 days of completing vaccination regimen.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;[3] Incorporates re-classifications of earlier reported cases.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;[4] Includes new cases added today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;[5] Based on National Immunisation Registry data.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;[6] Full regimen refers to individuals who have received both doses of the vaccine or one dose for vaccinated recovered individuals.&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:59:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:df08ae7c-dae5-4d83-bba1-1a6c34550df8</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/screen-for-life-waist-circumference-test/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Screen for Life Waist Circumference Test</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Mr Leon Perera&lt;br&gt;MP for Aljunied GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 933&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health given the recommendation in the HPB-MOH Clinical Practice Guidelines on Obesity (2016) that waist circumference measurement should be used in conjunction with Body Mass Index to identify increased disease risk (a) what is the rationale for the exclusion of the waist circumference measurement in obesity screening under the Screen for Life programme; and (b) whether the Government will consider the inclusion of waist circumference measurement in the Screen for Life programme and other standardised health screening tests.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Ministry of Health (MOH) takes reference from the Screening Test Review Committee (STRC) recommendations for the population-based screening tests offered under the Screen for Life (SFL) programme. The STRC reviews robust scientific evidence to ensure that the tests are safe, suitable, and cost-effective in detecting the condition screened for at a population level.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Body Mass Index (BMI) and waist circumference are both considered suitable population screening tests for obesity by the STRC. The BMI test was first included under SFL over the waist circumference measurement as the former was considered a more practical method to measure overweight / obesity, especially in mass screenings, and is done together with screening tests for diabetes, hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. To complement the BMI test, MOH is already in the process of including waist circumference measurement under SFL to assess individuals for abdominal obesity, as it is an indicator for higher cardiovascular risk, and will be implementing it soon.&lt;br&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:78cafa7f-f037-4952-beb9-c7ab27cc8b8a</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/healthcare-service-utilisation/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Healthcare service utilisation</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Dr Tan Wu Meng&lt;br&gt;MP for Jurong GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 929&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) in each of the past three years, with regard to HDB-resident Singaporeans over the age of 65, what are the median, 75th, 90th and 95th percentile outpatient polyclinic and specialist outpatient clinic attendance rates in the public hospitals, broken down by flat type; and (b) whether the Ministry can provide statistics on whether such residents have barrier-free access from their home to the nearest lift landing.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question No. 930&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) in each of the past three years, with regard to HDB-resident Singaporeans over the age of 65, what are the median, 75th, 90th and 95th percentile inpatient admission rates in the public hospitals by frequency of admission and total inpatient days, broken down by flat type; and (b) whether the Ministry can provide statistics on whether such residents have barrier-free access from their home to the nearest lift landing.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Over the past three years, the polyclinic attendance rate, specialist outpatient clinic (SOC) attendances rates, inpatient admission rates, and impatient bed days in the public hospitals for Singaporeans over the age of 65 and living in HDB estates, have remained generally stable&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;/sup&gt;. Those residing in smaller HDB flat types generally had higher utilisation of inpatient and polyclinic services, but lower utilisation of SOC services, compared to residents living in other housing types. See table below.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/default-album/pq_hsvc_table1.png?sfvrsn=dcb45095_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/default-album/pq_hsvc_table1.png?sfvrsn=dcb45095_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="PQ_HSVC_Table1" title="PQ_HSVC_Table1" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;p dir="ltr"&gt;The Government has taken measures to ensure barrier-free accessibility in our housing estates. In 1990, the Code on Barrier Free Accessibility in Buildings was first introduced to set minimum standards for barrier-free accessibility in and outside buildings. Since then, all new HDB estates are built with barrier-free access features, which include wider corridors for wheelchair movement, and a wheelchair accessible bathroom within the flat. Following the implementation of the Lift Upgrading Programme (LUP) for over 5,000 HDB blocks, the majority of HDB residents have barrier-free access from their home to the nearest lift landing. Residents of the remaining 2,000 flats without direct lift access who have medical or mobility issues can apply for the Lift access Housing Grant (LHG) of up to $30,000, to buy a new or resale HDB flat with direct lift access.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;span style="font-size: 10px;"&gt;&lt;sup&gt;1&lt;/sup&gt;The outpatient polyclinic statistics only include doctor visits to align with other settings. Non-doctor visits (e.g. for dental or allied health only) have been excluded.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:0738497b-616f-417a-ab9c-24f06613bf78</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/quarantine-procedure-for-foreign-domestic-workers-(fdws)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>QUARANTINE PROCEDURE FOR Foreign domestic workers (FDWs) </title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Ms Hazel Poa&lt;br&gt;Non-Constituency Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 899&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) what is the current quarantine procedure for foreign domestic workers (FDWs) arriving to work in Singapore; (b) under what circumstances can these FDWs be released early from their Stay Home Notices (SHNs); and (c) to date, how many FDWs have been released early from their SHNs.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Today, all travellers, including foreign domestic workers (FDWs) who have a recent travel history to higher risk countries/regions within the last 21 days prior to departure to Singapore would be subjected to a 14-day isolation at a dedicated Stay-Home Notice (SHN) facility. They are also subjected to a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test on arrival and on Day 14 of arrival, as well as self-administered Antigen Rapid Test (ART) tests on Days 3, 7 and 11 of arrival.&amp;nbsp; All travellers must test negative on their Day 14 PCR test to be released from the SHN.&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:99266b3f-3665-4736-a361-5a74dc194b4f</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/number-of-suicides-deaths-and-funding-on-suicide-prevention-programmes/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Number of suicides deaths and funding on suicide prevention programmes</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Mr Chua Kheng Wee Louis&lt;br&gt;MP for Sengkang GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 895&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health in each of the past five years (a) what is the number of suicides and attempted suicides by age group; and (b) in 2021 to date, what is the number of programmes and amount of funds dedicated specifically to suicide prevention services and promoting awareness of suicide warning signs&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;The number of suicide cases by age group is publicly released in the Report on Registration of Births and Deaths by the Immigration and Checkpoint Authority (ICA) on an annual basis. The annual number of suicide cases by age group in the past five years is summarised at Table 1.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/default-album/pq_table1.png?sfvrsn=9dfbf482_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/default-album/pq_table1.png?sfvrsn=9dfbf482_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="PQ_Table1" title="PQ_Table1" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Persons who are greatly distressed and attempt to take their own life require help and the criminal justice system may not be the best option to deal with attempted suicides. As of 1 January 2020, attempted suicide was decriminalised via the Criminal Law Reform Act 2019. The number of attempted suicides that the Police had attended to in the past five year is summarised at Table 2.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/default-album/pq_table2.png?sfvrsn=1b349785_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/default-album/pq_table2.png?sfvrsn=1b349785_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="PQ_Table2" title="PQ_Table2" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Suicide prevention spans several sectors including health, social and education, and are based on four key strategies: (1) building mental resilience, (2) encourage help seeking and early identification, (3) supporting at-risk groups, and (4) providing crisis support. Efforts under these strategies are integrated with mainstream mental health and well-being programmes implemented in various settings. These programmes received over $28 million from Government grants and community funds in Financial Year 2020.&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:7f81b3e2-b54b-431b-9c49-05739b5ec6ba</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/support-for-vulnerable-pregnant-women/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Support for vulnerable pregnant women</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Ms Nadia Ahmad Samdin&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;MP for Ang Mo Kio GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Question No. 885&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) whether it is mandatory for medical personnel to refer vulnerable pregnant women they encounter (including but not limited to single mothers or teenage mothers) to avenues for support and assistance during and post-pregnancy; and (b) what types of assistance are available to such individuals.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Healthcare professionals are legally required to notify the Police if they suspect that an offence, such as suspected sexual assault or physical abuse, has been committed under Section 424 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CPC). In addition, healthcare professionals are bound by professional ethical codes to make decisions in the best interests of their patients and to refer patients with needs that they are unable to address, to other avenues for appropriate care.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Pregnant women with identified needs are provided with psychosocial support and referred to medical social workers, nurses, care coordinators, as well as social and community services for relevant assistance as part of routine obstetric care.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;For example, to better support pregnant women from low-income families with symptoms of depression and anxiety, the National University Hospital (NUH) launched a pilot programme, Promoting Parental emotional health to Enhance child Learning (ProPEL), in 2018 to provide tailored interventions to these women during pregnancy and until the child turns one year old. Under this programme, case managers and social workers provide support and deliver cognitive-behavioural therapy and occupational therapy-based interventions through home visits, where necessary.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;In addition, under the KidSTART Home Visitation Programme, which is led by the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA), in partnership with the KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital (KKH) and NUH, home visitors equip low-income pregnant mothers and parents/caregivers of newborns with knowledge on early childhood development, health and nutrition up till the child is three years old.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To complement the efforts of public agencies, there are several ground-up initiatives within the community to support vulnerable pregnant women – Safe Place, an initiative by Lakeside Family Services, provides unsupported pregnant women and mothers with newborn babies a temporary place to stay for up to 4 months after giving birth, and offers them case management and counselling services. In addition, Babes Pregnancy Crisis Support provides casework and counselling for teenagers aged 21 and below who have difficulty in coping with their pregnancy, to help them make informed decisions regarding their pregnancy and parenting roles and provide them with parenting and self-care skills. It also offers befriending services to support the teenagers in their social and emotional well-being.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:a342643b-2b2e-4887-b923-c66290ae9851</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/subsidies-for-nursing-home-residents/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>Subsidies for Nursing Home residents</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Ms Carrie Tan&lt;br&gt;MP for Nee Soon GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 879&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health on a monthly and annual basis, how much does the Government spend on each elderly person who is cared for in nursing homes or other residential care facilities including salaries for staff, hygiene consumables and other paraphernalia related to care costs.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;In 2020, the Government provided around S$349 million in subsidies to 13,850 nursing home residents for nursing home services. This translates to an average of S$2,100 monthly or S$25,200 annually spent on each subsidised nursing home resident.&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:fa499421-abb0-4744-9aeb-b07589e83e4d</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/encourage-utilisation-and-expansion-of-elderly-befriender-services-to-reduce-elderly-suicide-rates/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>CHAT COMMUNITY OUTREACH TEAM AND SENIOR SUICIDES</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Mr Saktiandi Supaat, MP for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 1381&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) how many elderly persons have benefitted from CareLine since its roll-out and what is being done to raise awareness and encourage its usage; (b) whether more resources will be given to befriender services and suicide prevention groups; (c) whether the Silver Generation Office can increase the number of house visits to seniors living alone; and (d) what is the protocol when the senior declines assistance.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Ms Joan Pereira, MP for Tanjong Pagar GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 1392&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health with elderly suicides on the rise, whether the Ministry can provide resources to religious organisations to help address this issue.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Mr Leon Perera, MP for Aljunied GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 1411&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health (a) what is the take-up rate for the Community Health Assessment Team's (CHAT) services since the pandemic began; (b) whether the CHAT experience can be applied to mental health care for the wider community; (c) what is the number of referrals generated by the community mental health outreach teams set up by the Agency for Integrated Care together with community service partners in 2020; and (d) what is the strategy to ensure that older Singaporeans are accessing the mental health care&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Ministry of Health adopts a multi-pronged approach, comprising upstream prevention, supportive care as well as crisis intervention for those at-risk of mental health difficulties.&amp;nbsp; Under this approach, there are several channels of help:&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Institute of Mental Health’s (IMH’s) Mental Health Helpline, available to the public 24 hours daily, provides counseling for those suffering from psychological and psychiatric problems.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Within the community, Family Service Centres (FSCs) provide case management and counselling support to low-income and vulnerable individuals and families, to help them deal with financial and other difficulties.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;In addition, there are dedicated programmes for the young and old. IMH’s Community Health Assessment Team (CHAT) conducts outreach and mental health assessments for young people between 16 and 30 years old. In 2020, CHAT has performed more than 760 mental health assessments and close to 200 webCHAT sessions.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) has been working with community partners to provide persons at risk of mental health conditions or dementia, with related information and link them to community resources. As of end 2020, we have set up 50 community outreach teams, and reached out to more than 54,000 people in the community. AIC also supports and conducts e-training courses and provides relevant materials for community partners, including faith-based organisations.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Various initiatives are also in place to pre-empt social isolation, which is often associated with higher rates of depression, and higher suicide risks. For example, befrienders based in Eldercare Centres (ECs) make regular home visits and check-in calls to seniors needing support.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Silver Generation Office (SGO) complements this, by conducting targeted and frequent outreach to frail seniors and seniors who are living alone. If seniors decline assistance, SGOs will continue to build trust with the senior’s caregivers or community partners and establish at least one emergency contact whom the senior can approach in times of need.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;CareLine, a 24/7 social support hotline, provides tele-befriending as well as emergency response services to seniors in distress. As of May 2021, CareLine has supported around 10,000 vulnerable seniors, and has been collaborating with SGO and the ECs. Seniors may also contact other support hotlines such as The Seniors Helpline operated by Sage Counselling Centre, and Samaritans of Singapore Hotline, which provide counselling and suicide prevention resources.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;MOH will continue to work closely with our partners to develop community resources and build their capabilities to better support the mental health and well-being of the population.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:fd55a2d7-610b-4665-b29c-6012be531441</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/different-concentration-and-formulation-in-different-batches-of-oral-morphine-syrup-and-other-medications/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>DIFFERENT CONCENTRATION AND FORMULATION IN DIFFERENT BATCHES OF ORAL MORPHINE SYRUP AND OTHER MEDICATIONS</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Dr Tan Wu Meng&lt;br&gt;MP for Jurong GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 1367&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health with regard to oral morphine syrup used to treat patients with pain and breathlessness (a) why have certain batches been procured with different concentration and formulation containing 10% ethanol; (b) what is done to minimise error risk from different medication concentrations especially when administered by caregivers at home; and (c) for patients uncomfortable with ethanol-containing medication, what has been done to help patients access ethanol-free alternatives.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;br&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;The only registered Oral Morphine 1mg/mL Syrup (Statex) in Singapore was discontinued in 2019 as the plant ceased manufacturing the product. The Agency for Logistics and Procurement Services (ALPS) then brought in Oramorph 2mg/mL syrup, which contains Ethanol, for use in public healthcare institutions (PHIs). This was the only alternative that we were able to source for at that time.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Doctors were advised to offer non-alcohol based medications with the same analgesic effect instead of oral morphine solutions for their patients who could not take ethanol containing medication. ALPS has since procured a non-ethanol containing morphine syrup, Ra-morph 1 mg/ml preparation for the PHIs.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Each preparation is clearly labelled with the formulation and dosage instructions. Doctors, pharmacists and nurses work together to educate patients and caregivers on the differences in the medications and help them to switch from one formulation to another, when necessary.&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:d89bec2c-84cc-4619-862e-f2ff5b325e56</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/implications-of-claims-based-healthcare-insurance-pricing-on-older-policyholders-and-those-who-choose-to-move-to-public-healthcare-system/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>IMPLICATIONS OF CLAIMS-BASED HEALTHCARE INSURANCE PRICING ON OLDER POLICYHOLDERS AND THOSE WHO CHOOSE TO MOVE TO PUBLIC HEALTHCARE SYSTEM</title><description>&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Ms Mariam Jaafar&lt;br&gt;MP for Sembawang GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 1335&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health with regard to the introduction of claims-based health insurance pricing, what avenues exist to protect the interests of older policyholders and policyholders with pre-existing conditions.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Name and Constituency of Member of Parliament&lt;br&gt;Ms Mariam Jaafar, MP for Sembawang GRC&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Question No. 1346&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;To ask the Minister for Health with regard to the introduction of claims based insurance pricing, what is the number of Integrated Shield Plan holders who have switched to MediShield Life and moved into the public healthcare system.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Written Answer&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Riders are optional private insurance products that are paid for by policyholders in cash, to provide as-charged and zero copayment coverage. Since 2019, MOH has required a minimum 5% co-payment for all new rider productsto mitigate the risk of a ‘buffet syndrome’ and avoid unsustainable healthcare cost and insurance premium increases. Some insurers have chosen to implement the co-payment directly, through claims-based pricing (CBP), or a combination of the two.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Regardless of the healthcare insurance plans they choose, all Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents are covered under MediShield Life, which is a basic health insurance plan that provides lifelong protection against large hospital bills regardless of pre-existing conditions. This protects the interests of all policyholders, including older Singaporeans who have pre-existing conditions. This can be supplemented with optional IPs if higher coverage is preferred. MediSave can be used for MediShield Life and IP premiums, and these are not subject to CBP.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;Policyholders should carefully assess the terms of their private rider policy plans, and consider discussing with their insurer a plan that is suitable for their needs.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;There is currently no evidence to show that CBP shifts claims to public hospitals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 15:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:2865a21d-0385-4c89-a5bd-8141a29fcc04</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/ministerial-statement-by-mr-ong-ye-kung-minister-for-health-on-development-of-the-covid-19-pandemic-26-july-2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>MINISTERIAL STATEMENT BY MR ONG YE KUNG, MINISTER FOR HEALTH ON DEVELOPMENT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, 26 JULY 2021</title><description>Mr Deputy Speaker Sir&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;1.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Today, my fellow co-chairs of the Multi-Ministry Task Force (MTF), Minister Gan Kim Yong and Minister Lawrence Wong, and I will be delivering Ministerial Statements to update members on the COVID-19 situation in Singapore.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Our Ministerial Statements will address Oral Questions 1 to 5, and 26 to 28, and Written Questions 28, 29 and 31 to 33 of today’s Order Paper.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;It will cover questions on the KTV and Jurong Fishery Port clusters, our COVID-19 vaccination programme, and our plans to transit to live normally with COVID-19.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Murali Pillai, Assoc Prof Jamus Lim, Mr Darryl David, Mr Xie Yao Quan, Mr Yip Hon Weng, Mr Seah Kian Peng, Ms Raeesah Khan, and Mr Sitoh Yih Pin - have filed Oral and Written PQs scheduled for future sittings on these issues.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As today’s Ministerial Statements would address those questions, Mr Deputy Speaker Sir, I would like to invite Members to seek clarifications on these issues after the Ministerial Statements.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Should their queries be sufficiently addressed, it may not be necessary for them to proceed with their PQs for the future sittings.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The KTV Cluster&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;On Monday 12 Jul 21, MOH detected several COVID-19 positive cases amongst individuals who frequented KTV bars and lounges.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;These individuals included patrons of the bars and hostesses who worked in the lounges.&amp;nbsp; These activities were considered very high risk and had been disallowed since the beginning of the pandemic.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;9.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The cluster grew rapidly, and MOH moved in quickly to isolate infected persons, identify rings of contacts and tested them for COVID-19.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;10.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We ordered a two-week suspension of operations in all pivoted nightlife establishments from 16 July till 30 July.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;11.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The pivoted nightlife establishments cannot resume operations until they pass inspections to ensure that safe management measure protocols are in place, and they have received written approval.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;12.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Xie Yao Quan asked if we would consider making the individuals in the KTV cluster pay for their COVID-19 medical expenses in full.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;13.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We are all upset by the irresponsible behaviour of individuals involved in the KTV cluster, but we have a public responsibility to ensure that everyone receives the medical care that they need.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;14.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We also do not want individuals, especially those who are infected, to avoid getting tested and treated, or hide where they have been from contact tracers, because they are afraid of getting penalised. This will make it harder to contain the spread, and could cost us more in the long run.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;15.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We were on the path towards progressive opening, and the KTV cluster was a major unexpected bump on the road.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;16.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The MTF deliberated on the matter, and on the advice of our medical experts, came to the conclusion that given our extensive tracing and testing efforts, and our population vaccination rate for two doses was approaching 50%, the cluster ought not significantly change our plans to open up.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;17.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Hence on 16 July, the MTF announced our decision to maintain our then current safe management posture. We made some adjustments to the rules for eating in restaurants, to allow groups of five to dine together, provided everyone is fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;18.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Based on how the cluster has developed, we still believe that was the correct call. As of 25 July 2021, the KTV cluster has a total of 237 infected persons. For the past three days, the daily increase in infection for the cluster was 6, 5 and 5 respectively.&amp;nbsp; It is coming under control.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;19.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Unfortunately, things got derailed due to the next and troublesome cluster that we detected.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Jurong Fishery Port Cluster&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;20.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;On the evening of Friday, 16 July 2021, we started to detect multiple infections at Jurong Fishery Port, as well as in Hong Lim market.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;21.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This involved fishmongers and stall assistants going about earning an honest living, collecting fish at the fishery port, but unwittingly getting infected, and then transmitting to more people in the markets and communities where they ply their trade.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;22.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;MOH, with the help of NEA, took immediate steps to prevent further spread by stopping the fishmongers and their assistants from setting up their stalls on Sunday, 18 July 2021. We then issued Health Risk Warnings which required them to undergo PCR tests and isolated themselves until they get negative results.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;23.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Of the 1,548 tested, 43 were found to be COVID-19 positive, which indicated that significant community transmission had most likely already silently occurred in the days prior to 18 July 2021.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;24.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Markets are frequented by wide segments of the public, particularly seniors, of whom one quarter are still not fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp; The risk of infections rising uncontrollably could not be ruled out. These infections could potentially result in more cases of severe illness and even deaths among our vulnerable senior population.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;25.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Hence, the MTF decided to pre-emptively dial back to Phase Two (Heightened Alert). This came into effect on 22 July 2021. We did this to buy ourselves precious time to get more of our population vaccinated, so that we can continue on our path towards living with COVID-19 safely.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;26.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The preliminary phylogenetic findings suggest that while the KTV and Jurong Fishery Port clusters were all driven by the Delta variant, it is distinct from the Delta variant that infected Tan Tock Seng Hospital and Changi Airport clusters.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt; &lt;br&gt;27.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The recent clusters have a Delta strain that is more closely related to what we detected in imported cases from our immediate region.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;28.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;However, there are also slight genetic differences between the strains in the two clusters, suggesting that there were multiple introduction points.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;29.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 25 July 2021, the Jurong Fishery Port has a total of 792 cases.&amp;nbsp; It is still growing, but now at a slower rate. The daily infections numbers over the past three days were 79, 79 and 46 respectively.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;30.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Overall, we have seen a high number of daily cases at over 100 for the past few days. But the situation is stabilizing, with daily infections trending down.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;31.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Percentage of cases isolated or quarantined before turning COVID-19 positive is something we watched closely and it is on an upward trend.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;On 19 July, when the cluster first broke out, we had a total of 163 cases, with only 27% isolated before detection. Lately, it hovers around 40%.&amp;nbsp; Today, we should have more than half of our cases already isolated.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;32.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;If we can keep raising that percentage through tracing and testing, we can progressively suppress this wave of transmission.&amp;nbsp; But our objective is not to stop transmissions completely. That is no longer possible given how transmissible the Delta variant is, and as we open up and people circulate more.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;33.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The only possible way now to eradicate infections is to go into another hard Circuit Breaker for at least a month or probably two. But we don’t want to be locked up.&amp;nbsp; Even if we do, once we open up, cases will rise again.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;34.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Eradication is therefore not possible nor sustainable. We must instead find ways to live with this virus, safely.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;35.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Several Members, namely Mr Yip Hon Weng, Assoc Prof Jamus Lim, Ms Raeesah Khan, were interested to find out more about our transition plans to live with COVID-19, as an endemic disease.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Pushing Up Vaccination Rates&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;36.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Vaccinations are key to this transition, and the national programme is progressing well.&amp;nbsp; As of 25 July, 54% of our population has received two doses of a mRNA vaccine.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;37.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Our population vaccination rate is going up by about one percentage point a day. By National Day, almost 70% will have received two doses. By early-September, it should be almost 80%.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;38.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This means Singapore will have one of the highest vaccination rates in the world.&amp;nbsp; It puts us in a strong position to transit to a COVID resilient society.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;39.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Our main worry is that our seniors, especially those 70 and above, are not sufficiently vaccinated. Today, just over 70% of them have received two doses of the vaccines.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;40.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Ms Tin Pei Ling asked for an update on the home vaccination scheme.&amp;nbsp; We have launched nine home vaccination teams so far.&amp;nbsp; As of 23 July, 734 seniors have received vaccinations under the programme.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;41.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Further, more seniors are coming forward to our vaccination centres and mobile vaccination teams. We have been seeing about 500 seniors coming forward daily. For the past few days, this has more than doubled to over 1,000 a day.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;42.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This may be due to heightened awareness as a result of more community transmissions, the lifting of rules that had previously deferred vaccinations of those with medical conditions, and our intense outreach efforts.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;43.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Our mobile teams have gone all the way to Pulau Ubin to administer vaccines to seniors living there. We know of GPs who persuaded their clients to go for vaccinations, and then allowed them to sit in their clinics for the entire day, to assure them that help is always nearby should they feel unwell after vaccinations.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;44.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Deputy Speaker Sir, this is a measure of the kind of society we are. We are making such an extraordinary effort with our seniors because we are not prepared to accept the high fatality rates among the elderly that other countries had or are experiencing.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;45.&amp;nbsp; As a result of all these efforts, 77% of our seniors 70 and above have now received their first doses. Within a month or so, they should all have received their second doses, and after another 14 days, they should all be strongly protected against COVID-19.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;46.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Even at our current rate of vaccination, the preliminary evidence is that it has been effective in reducing the incidence of severe illnesses and deaths.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;47.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Deputy Speaker Sir, may I show a chart on screen please?&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;48.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As Members can see, while daily infections have gone up sharply for the past couple of weeks, the number of patients with severe illness who require oxygen supplementation or are in an Intensive Care Unit, remains relatively low.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;49.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Currently, all of these patients with severe illnesses, are either unvaccinated or partially vaccinated. But we are watching this closely, as there is a time lag of one to two weeks between infection and the onset of severe illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;50.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;For now, it would appear that we have successfully weakened the link between infections and severe illnesses.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;We Must Be Able to Live Normally With COVID-19&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;51.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;While we are making good progress in vaccinating our people, we acknowledge that the recent reversion to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) has caused some confusion amongst members of the public. They ask: are we still committed to the path towards normalcy and living with COVID-19?&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;52.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The answer is a definite yes. For that is the only way for Singaporeans to regain our lives and livelihoods, and for Singapore to reconnect with the world again.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;53.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Some countries, like the UK, have declared a Freedom Day, where all social restrictions are lifted at once. Others, like Israel and Netherlands, opened up and saw sharp increases in infections and hospitalisations, and decided to dial back.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;54.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Ours will be a controlled opening. We are not going to do a big bang – and then predictably blow up. The MTF has been developing a roadmap, comprising packages of measures to be implemented step-by-step, over the next few months.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;55.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;But even as we do so, we must bear in mind that until we reach a sufficiently high vaccination rate, especially among our seniors, we will continue to be vulnerable to unexpected setbacks, like what we are going through now.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;56&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; A high rate of vaccination will provide us with a more solid and stable base as we proceed on this journey. The higher the vaccination rate, the more solid the ground we walk on.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;57.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;So, in a way, this is the most peculiar period of our transition: We are clear about the mission; our will is firm; and we have a broad plan. But we don’t have enough antibodies inside us to ensure that we can follow through with our plans without a hitch.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;58.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;But let us not underestimate the progress we have made.&amp;nbsp; The roadmap is in fact being implemented as we speak.&amp;nbsp; Our attention is often on the Safe Management Measures such as whether we can eat in restaurants, but there at least three other important aspects, namely:&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;a.&amp;nbsp; Restoring economic and social activities, including connecting with the outside world;&lt;br&gt;b.&amp;nbsp; Remodelling COVID-19 healthcare protocols; and&lt;br&gt;c.&amp;nbsp; Shifting our collective psychology, which will probably be the hardest.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;59.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Minister Gan will speak about restoring economic activities, while Minister Lawrence Wong will speak more about enabling more social activities.&amp;nbsp; Let me talk about healthcare protocols and our collective psychology.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Shifts In Healthcare Protocols&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;60.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As we learn to live with COVID-19, our healthcare protocols must be remodelled.&amp;nbsp; If COVID-19 is indeed endemic, having 200 or more cases a day may not be unusual at all.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;61.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;During an Influenza season, our daily infection can go up to 1,000 a day.&amp;nbsp; Imagine we treat Influenza like we treat COVID-19 now.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;62.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We will put everyone suspected of Influenza infections through PCR tests and long isolated stays in hospitals, and quarantine everyone they came into contact.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;63.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;It will disrupt the lives of many people.&amp;nbsp; Further hospital beds will all be filled, and many other patients who are sicker will be turned away. The healthcare system will not be able to cope, and that is clearly not the way to deal with an endemic disease.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;64.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We cannot carry on with the current healthcare protocols for COVID-19.&amp;nbsp; They need to shift closer to how we treat Influenza today, without extensive contact tracing and quarantine in dedicated facilities, and hospitalizing only those who are very ill.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;65.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;But that can only happen when the likelihood of developing very serious or life-threatening disease as a result of COVID-19 infection has been significantly reduced by effective vaccination of our population, especially among the vulnerable groups.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;66.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;With our current rate of vaccinations, we have started to take the first transition step to remodel our healthcare protocols.&amp;nbsp; As of last week, we made the following changes:&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;67.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;First, greater use of community care facilities instead of hospitals. Vaccinated individuals aged between 45 and 59 who test positive for Covid-19 and show no or mild symptoms, can be directly admitted to community care facilities instead of going first to hospitals.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;68.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This was already the practice for all cases aged between 17 and 45 years, but we are expanding the protocol to people up to age 59.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;69.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; With this change, we expect up to 60% of infected cases to recover in community care facilities, instead of in acute care hospitals. Meanwhile, we will plan for the next step, where perhaps 80% can be admitted to community care facilities, and some can even recover at home.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;70.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Second, we have shortened the length of stay in hospitals and community care facilities.&amp;nbsp; Our tests have shown that the viral load in infected persons who are fully vaccinated falls very rapidly, to a very low level after nine days.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;71.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Previously, most people generally were discharged only after 21 days.&amp;nbsp; We are now discharging fully vaccinated persons from isolation after 14 days from onset of illness with a seven-day leave of absence, so long as their tests show that they are COVID-19 negative or have very low viral loads.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;72.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We are reviewing our policy to allow fully vaccinated patients to be discharged even earlier, and to complete the rest of the isolation period at home, if their home environment is suitable.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;73.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Third, greater use of home quarantine. For fully vaccinated persons, they can now serve their quarantine at home instead of at a government quarantine facility, provided that their home is suitable for isolation.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;74.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We expect up to 40% of persons under quarantine can serve their quarantine at home, and this will go beyond 50% in the coming few weeks as more people get vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Shifts in Collective Psychology&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;75.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;These are among first steps we will take in the healthcare transition. In the meantime, what we are experiencing in this current wave of transmission is valuable, for we are also witnessing a palpable shift in our collective psychology.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;76.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The first is a shift away from always focusing on infection numbers.&amp;nbsp; We used to get a shock when we saw high daily numbers, because that meant more severe illnesses and deaths.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;77.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;However, in recent days, that mental link is starting to be broken, as we know that with vaccinations, high infection numbers need not necessarily mean more sickness and deaths.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;78.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Many people are now rightfully focusing on the number of people with severe illnesses.&amp;nbsp; As of today, despite higher infection cases over the past few days, that number is 14, and does not threaten our hospital capacity.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;79.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Many friends, including some Members of this House, have been texting me asking why don’t we publish the number of people with severe illnesses so that we know vaccination works?&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;80.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Actually, the media have been publishing these numbers every day for quite a while now.&amp;nbsp; But our attention has always been on infection numbers.&amp;nbsp; It is good that attention is now shifting.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;81.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;A second shift is a greater acceptance of differentiated safe management measures, between those who are vaccinated and those who are not. There have been many calls to do this. Mr Xie Yao Quan has also asked about this.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;82.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This is something which the MTF has always intended to do. That was why we decided on the 2/5 rule for restaurants recently, before it was scuttled with our reversion to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert).&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;83.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;When our whole society is very highly vaccinated and we have transitioned to living with COVID-19, we should make very little differentiation between the vaccinated and the unvaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;84.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;But during the period of transition, when we are still building up our resilience, differentiation by vaccination status is a practical way to open up some activities first, while protecting those who are still vulnerable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;85.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;MTF will revisit this during our Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) midpoint review. Minister Lawrence Wong will speak more about this later.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Addressing Other Questions&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;86.&amp;nbsp; Let me address several other questions from Members.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;87.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Murali Pillai will be comforted to know that MOH actively monitors international developments in medical treatment options for COVID-19, through the National Centre of Infectious Diseases (NCID) and an expert committee.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;88.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;They have developed national treatment guidelines which are constantly updated based on new evidence.&amp;nbsp; They provide guidance to our doctors on the use of evidence-based medical treatment options for COVID-19 patients.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;89.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Our local institutions have also been participating actively in international multi-centre trials investigating novel COVID-19 therapeutics. These trials have generated important data on new COVID-19 treatments such as remdesivir.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;90.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We will continue to closely monitor developments in COVID-19 treatments, proactively procure therapeutic agents which are shown to be effective, and maintain a stockpile based on projected needs.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;91.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;To Mr Leon Perera’s question, factors that affect COVID-19 vaccine efficacy are an area of active study in Singapore. Persons who have contracted COVID-19 are clinically assessed for risk factors and scientific papers on the correlations may be published in future.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;92.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Antibody testing is not required after vaccination, under Singapore’s national vaccination programme, and we are actively reviewing the need for vaccine boosters.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;93.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We are also continually reviewing Singapore’s portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines. We plan to bring in non-mRNA vaccines that are robustly assessed for quality, safety and effectiveness.&amp;nbsp; This should happen before the end of the year, subject to supply and regulatory approval.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;94.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Testing will remain important, even as we transit to living with COVID-19.&amp;nbsp; It is only through testing, that we can know if we are infected, and do the civic-minded thing in excusing ourselves from work and staying home.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;95.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;But we have to make testing simple, accessible, and affordable – even more so than now -- so that we can all do our part.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;96.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Since mid-June, we have progressively rolled out regular Fast and Easy Tests for staff working in higher-risk settings. This includes a network of sixteen Quick Test Centres, which we intend to expand further.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;97.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;In response to Ms Joan Pereira’s question, the Quick Test Centres will support small businesses by allowing their staff to walk in and get themselves tested and have their results recorded. At some point, I believe some Quick Test Centres should also be using breathalyser tests.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;98.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We will continue to work with NEA to deploy wastewater testing across Singapore. Currently, NEA has deployed 270 autosamplers across about 200 sites. We are increasing this to 500 autosamplers across 400 sites by end of this year.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;99.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Wastewater testing is an increasingly strategic resource as we learn to live with COVID-19.&amp;nbsp; We can deploy them in areas where we suspect transmission is happening such as around all the markets that are currently affected , or where we know many unvaccinated seniors live.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;100.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Such testing is non-intrusive, and would give us valuable early warning when COVID-19 starts to take hold in a locality, and prompts us to take further public health measures in the affected residential estates.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;101.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Darryl David, Dr Lim Wee Kiak and Mr Murali Pillai, asked about the safety of the COVID-19 vaccines. MOH has been publishing monthly safety updates on our website.&amp;nbsp; It also gives an age breakdown of the affected persons, and indeed the majority are young people.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;102.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 30 June 2021, HSA had received 12 reports of myocarditis and pericarditis occurring in persons after receiving a dose of the mRNA-based COVID vaccine. While there is a small increased risk among those in the younger age groups relative to the baseline rate, the local incidence rate remains low.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;102.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;One of the reported cases is a full-time national serviceman in the Singapore Armed Forces who is below 30 years old. None of the cases was from the Singapore Police Force and Singapore Civil Defence Force.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;103.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We implemented the Vaccine Injury Financial Assistance Programme or VIFAP to give greater peace of mind to people taking the vaccination.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;104.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;But remember that with or without vaccination, there is a baseline number of disease cases amongst our population. Since the vast majority of Singaporeans have stepped forward to be vaccinated, there will naturally be numerous incidents which just happen to coincide with vaccinations.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;105.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Hence, we have to do what is practical and reasonable, which is to have VIFAP applications reviewed by a panel of medical experts, who will consider them against known evidence about the vaccines.&lt;br&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;106.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;A few Members have also asked about the Sinovac-CoronaVac (Sinovac) vaccine. As at 25 July 2021, about 72,000 persons have received at least one dose of the Sinovac vaccine, and about 17,000 persons have received their second doses. Amongst them 28% are Singapore Citizens, and they are mostly young. For those who have taken the Sinovac vaccine and are seniors above 60 years old, less than 10% are Singaporeans.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;107.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;If the supply of 200,000 doses which the Government has procured is insufficient to cater to the demand, private clinics can bring in additional supply, as is the case for any other WHO EUL vaccine, under the Special Access Route.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;108.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As of 9 July 2021, HSA had received 10 adverse event reports following vaccination with the Sinovac vaccine comprising mainly allergic reactions such as itch and rashes.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;109.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As for concessions on safe management measures, the data on the efficacy of the Sinovac vaccine against the Delta variant is still building up.&amp;nbsp; Sinovac has also recently submitted the required safety data for their application for the Pandemic Special Access Route approval.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;110.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;The Health Sciences Authority and our Expert Committee are going through the various data.&amp;nbsp; When the evidence justifies it, we will certainly want to extend the concessions to individuals who have received the Sinovac or other vaccines which may qualify.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Conclusion - Progressing with Unity&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;111.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Deputy Speaker Sir, let me conclude.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;112.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;As a Government, we need to recognize that our society is diverse, with different segments of the population having different opinions, needs and wants.&amp;nbsp; When these differences cannot be reconciled, we agree to disagree, and live and let live.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;113.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;At the same time, we do our best to unite and forge a consensus, for what is a society without shared commonalities?&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;114.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This is what a responsible Government needs to do across a range of issues -- from education, healthcare and public housing, to racial harmony and free trade. We must always try to strike the right balance between forging consensus and respecting diverse views.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;115.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;It is the same when it comes to learning to live with COVID-19.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;116.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;On the one hand, we have the young, vaccinated individuals who feel that we should open up and allow vaccinated individuals to enjoy more social activities.&amp;nbsp; On the other,&amp;nbsp; we still have a sizeable segment of older Singaporeans who for medical or other reasons, are yet to be vaccinated, and who remain vulnerable.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;117.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Differentiated safe management measures is something we have to put in place&amp;nbsp; for public health reasons, and to protect the unvaccinated.&amp;nbsp; At the same time, we must do our best to get more of the vulnerable vaccinated. As I reported just now, we are making progress.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;118.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;And for the non-vulnerable, as more of you get vaccinated, when you show more consideration to others, you are also doing your part to better protect the vulnerable. Remember, our children, nieces or nephews or younger brothers and sisters, under 12, will not be vaccinated for a while yet.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;119.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;When we work together as a people, we will bring ourselves to a much stronger and more resilient position, and our transition to living with COVID-19 will gather pace.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;120.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Mr Deputy Speaker Sir, Singapore is one of the few countries to have come through the last 20 months of the pandemic with very few fatalities. And we can look forward with confidence to living with an endemic COVID-19 because a high proportion of our population will be fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;121.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Most of the developing world still has little access to vaccines. But even among the countries and regions which have the vaccines, Singapore is unique.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;122.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;We have one group -- including the US, UK, Israel and many EU countries --&amp;nbsp; which went through major episodes of widespread transmission, their hospitals overwhelmed and with many fatalities. They are now highly vaccinated and opening up their economies and societies.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;123.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;And then there are the likes of Australia, New Zealand, and Hong Kong, who kept the pandemic under control, but are now finding it a challenge to get their people vaccinated, partly because their lives have not been very threatened by COVID-19.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;124.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This will make us perhaps the only country in the world, which has not suffered a collapse of our hospitals nor a high death toll, and at the same time achieved a very high vaccination rate in our population.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;125.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;This uniqueness is due to the unity of our people, the trust amongst them, and between the people and Government. We can look towards The Road Ahead with confidence and optimism. Thank you.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description><pubDate>Mon, 26 Jul 2021 14:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:d500dad8-989b-409f-aa27-c3f026ff8f36</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/129-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-covid-19-infection-26jul2021/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>129 NEW CASES OF LOCALLY TRANSMITTED COVID-19 INFECTION</title><description>As of 26 July 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has preliminarily confirmed 129 new cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection, of which 61 are linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and 6 belong to the KTV cluster. Of the 129 cases today, 76 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 25 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 28 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases is 1 senior above 70 years who is partially vaccinated, and is at risk of serious illness.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In addition, there are 6 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 3 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 3 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 135 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; We are still working through the details of the cases, and further updates will be shared via the MOH press release that will be issued tonight.</description><pubDate>Sun, 25 Jul 2021 16:00:00 Z</pubDate><a10:content type="text"></a10:content></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">urn:uuid:22d76ab7-031e-468b-895c-45297aa84364</guid><link>https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-local-covid-19-situation-(25-july-2021)/</link><a10:author><a10:name> </a10:name></a10:author><title>UPDATE ON LOCAL COVID-19 SITUATION (25 JULY 2021)</title><description>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; As of 25 July 2021, 12pm, the Ministry of Health (MOH) has confirmed and verified that there are 117 cases of locally transmitted COVID-19 infection, of which 46 are linked to the Jurong Fishery Port cluster and 5 belong to the KTV cluster. Of the 117 cases today, 43 are linked to previous cases, and have already been placed on quarantine. 36 are linked to previous cases and were detected through surveillance. 38 are currently unlinked. Amongst the cases are 2 seniors above 70 years who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, and are at risk of serious illness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;2.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There are 8 imported cases, who have already been placed on Stay-Home Notice (SHN) or isolated upon arrival in Singapore. 4 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 4 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;3.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; In total, there are 125 new cases of COVID-19 infection in Singapore today.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 1: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Community Unlinked Cases, and Linked Cases by Already Quarantined/ Detected through Surveillance, and Dormitory Resident Cases[1]&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig1(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=f422cd9f_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig1(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=f422cd9f_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig1(25Jul21)" title="Fig1(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Condition of confirmed cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;4.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; 524 cases are currently warded in hospital.&amp;nbsp; Most are well and under observation. There are currently 12 cases of serious illness requiring oxygen supplementation, and 2 in critical condition in the intensive care unit (ICU). None amongst these 14 cases is fully vaccinated. 7 seniors above 60 years, who are completely unvaccinated or partially vaccinated, have fallen very ill.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 2:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig2(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=e834a7f4_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig2(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=e834a7f4_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig2(25Jul21)" title="Fig2(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 3: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;by Age Group&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig3(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=27c9506b_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig3(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=27c9506b_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig3(25Jul21)" title="Fig3(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;5.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There is continuing evidence that vaccination helps to prevent serious disease when one gets infected. Over the last 28 days, 15 local cases required oxygen supplementation, were admitted to ICU or passed away. 6 are unvaccinated, 9 are partially vaccinated and none was fully vaccinated.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 4:&lt;/strong&gt; Local Cases in the Last 28 Days by Vaccination Status &amp;amp; Severity of Condition[2]&lt;div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig4(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=9b33bfef_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig4(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=9b33bfef_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig4(25Jul21)" title="Fig4(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 5: &lt;/strong&gt;Deaths and Active Cases in ICU or Requiring Oxygen Supplementation,&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;by Vaccination Status[2]&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig5(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=e7c1d8a5_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig5(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=e7c1d8a5_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig5(25Jul21)" title="Fig5(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for local cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;6.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; Overall, the number of new cases in the community has increased from 324 cases in the week before to 1,056 cases in the past week. We are likely to continue to see high number of cases in the coming days as we step up efforts to detect them to contain their spread in the community. The number of unlinked cases in the community has also increased from 24 cases in the week before to 136 cases in the past week. The 7-day moving average number of all linked community cases and all unlinked community cases are 131.4 and 19.4 respectively.&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 6: &lt;/strong&gt;7 Day Moving Average Number of Community Unlinked and Linked Cases[3]&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig6(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=492c047b_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig6(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=492c047b_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig6(25Jul21)" title="Fig6(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 7:&lt;/strong&gt; Community Unlinked and Linked Cases in the Last 14 Days, by Detection Method&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig7(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=b55d7c25_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig7(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=b55d7c25_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig7(25Jul21)" title="Fig7(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 8: &lt;/strong&gt;Local Cases in the Last 14 Days by Age Group and Vaccination Status&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig8(25jul21)22bf8a09e23a45e98cd2ccbfc91af44a.png?sfvrsn=c85cfaa_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig8(25jul21)22bf8a09e23a45e98cd2ccbfc91af44a.png?sfvrsn=c85cfaa_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig8(25Jul21)" title="Fig8(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Summary of trends for imported cases&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;7.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There are a total of 8 imported cases today. 4 were detected upon arrival in Singapore, while 4 developed the illness during SHN or isolation.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 9:&lt;/strong&gt; Number of Imported Cases by Detected Upon Arrival/&amp;nbsp;Detected during SHN or Isolation&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig9(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=a2b187d6_0"&gt;&lt;img src="https://www.moh.gov.sg/images/librariesprovider5/covid-19-chart-(pr)/fig9(25jul21).png?sfvrsn=a2b187d6_0" data-displaymode="Original" alt="Fig9(25Jul21)" title="Fig9(25Jul21)" data-openoriginalimageonclick="true"&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Active clusters under monitoring&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;8.&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; There are 2 new clusters today. In total, there are currently 25 active clusters, ranging between 3 and 792&amp;nbsp; infections. MOH has been monitoring existing clusters for any further transmission. As there have been no more cases linked to the 115 Bukit Merah View Market &amp;amp; Food Centre, 119 Bukit Merah View and Case 64394 clusters for the past two incubation periods (i.e. 28 days), the clusters have now been closed.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Figure 10: &lt;/strong&gt;Number of Active Clusters&lt;br&gt;&lt;a Crescent&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p 64478&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p align="center"&gt;0&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td width="115" valign="top"&gt;&lt;p
